characters: VIEW ON THE FACES OF THE P.B.R. CREW
MED. VIEW ON WILLARD AND LANCE
VIEW ON THE MEN IN THE WATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The VIEW finally SETTLES ON a partically luxury cabin cruiser harbored at a particular dock late in the day. It is large, pleasure boat: The people are relaxing in bathing suits and towels and robes. They are drinking cocktails, and snapping pictures. The boat belongs to the head of a large American Corporation, and this is his party. This man, CHARLIE, is sitting, his shirt off to catch some of the late sun. Others have their faces smeared with white suntan oil that reminds us of war paint. Charlie is going on and on :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... It's crazy -- sugar is up to 200 dollars a ton -- sugar !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about oil ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Food, oil --look, let me show you something. This is the economy of the United States in two years -- He takes a newspaper, draws a circle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is West Germany. (he draws another, bigger circle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Japan. (another , bigger)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Italy. (a dot)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Iran. (a very big circle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is Saudi Arabia... In two years ? (a gigantic circle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you understand ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's to prevent it ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe nothing. But I'll tell you, I didn't build a two-billion-dollar company in the last twenty years by doing nothing. We can protect our interests. (pause, for a drink)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are still the most powerful nation in the world. Militarily. He leans to his associates, in a half-whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know bodyguard; he was a captain in Viet Nam. You talk to him, except he won't talk. This kind of man can kill you with his pinky. A nice quiet fella, though. The VIEW BEGINS TO PULL AWAY from this group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carries a attache case at all times. You know what's in it ? (another sip)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Ingram Machine pistol. Gradually, Charlie's voice softens as we MOVE AWAY, and a NEW VOICE, the voice of someone thinking, COMES IN OVER i

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE WILLARD
dialogues.text: I don't tahe chances, and                        Bullshit neither should this country.                        with If we're strong, we should                        hand to protect our interests, and                        can cru we should have the respect                        your kn of the world, even if it                                c takes another war.                                your pi The VIEW MOVE ALONG the guests of this small party : Pictures being taken, some people are swimming. It is the good life. Now WILLARD'S VOICE TRACK DOMINATES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The attache case has been empty for three years, but it makes him safe to think there's a machine pistol in it. I don't like automatic weapons. They jam. I saw a friend of mine get ripped open because he flicked his M-16 to automatic, and it jammed. How much money did the contractors make on the M-16 ? Our VIEW IS MOVING through the people on the boat; some reading, flirting, drinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He likes to hear stories about Nam. I tell him I can't; they're not cleared. The truth is he wouldn't understand. We can now SEE A MAN with his BACK TO US, looking the opposite way. An attache case resting near to him. We  MOVE CLOSER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no way I can tell them... what really happened over there. I wouldn't've believed it if someone'd told me. We are now RESTING on his back. Occasionally, he sips from a beer, but we cannot see his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was only one part that mattered -- for me, anyway. I don't even know if I remember all of it. I can't remember how it ended, exactly -- because when it ended I was insane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Saigon boom street in late 1968. There are bars and shops for servicemen; the rickshaws, the motorbikes. Our VIEW MOVES TOWARD one particular officer; B.L. WILLARD , in uniform, a Captain of the Airborne, followed by four or five Vietnamese kids trying to shine his shoes and sell him things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I know how it started for me -- I was on R. and R. in Saigon; my first time south of the DMZ in three months. I wasn't sure, but I thought this guy was following me. Willard looks back.

dialogues.speaker: HIS VIEW
dialogues.text: an American CIVILIAN.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: Willard ducks into a bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much in this place -- a bar, linoleum flooring, a few tables and chairs, and a juke box. The lounge is fairly crowded. Willard takes off his cap and walks quietly past the soldiers at the bar. Some of them, catching sight of his ribbons, stop talking as he moves by. An INFANTRY CAPTAIN enters the bar, buys a couple of drinks and approaches Willard's table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about a drink ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, thanks. He sits down at the table with the drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winning the war by yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he calls for the waiter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which part is that ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My part. (TO THE WAITER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beer, with ice and water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good gin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure it is, but I had hepatitis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delta ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: North ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Way north.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What unit were you with ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rangers, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sort of. The JUKE BOX starts BLARING. Annoyed , Willard looks over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you Longe Range Recon --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- I worked too far north for LRRP. He reaches into his shirt pocket for a cigarette, and the Captain leans over the table to light it for him. Willard notices the CIVILIAN on the street has glanced in the bar then enters and sits down at a table by the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's quite an array of ribbons...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's talk about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was an FO for the 25th.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tracks ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fat. That's real fat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least you always have enough water. How many gallons does each one of those damn things carry ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty -- sometimes fifty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I can remember once, getting back below the DMZ -- and the first Americans we ran into were a track squadron. I just couldn't believe how much water they had. We'd been chewing bamboo shoots for almost a week, and before that, for two weeks, we'd been drinking anything -- rain water, river shit, stuff right out of the paddies. And there were these guys standing by their trucks spilling water all over. I could've killed them. (solemnly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear to God I would have, too, if ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know we had units up there in North Vietnam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long were you up there ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A year ? Waiter another beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I go up on missions. Listen Captain, buy me all the beer you want, but you better tell that asshole over there you're not going to find out anymore about me. Willard glances over his shoulder and indicates the Civilian. The Civilian is given a sign by the Captain. He rises and comes over to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating the Army jeep)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're B.L. Willard, 4th Recon Group, we'd like you to come with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose orders ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Headquarters 11 Corps -- 405th A.S.A Battalion -- S-2 -- Com-Sec -- Intelligence -- Nha Trang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The agency. Willard looks at the Civilian a moment, and then walks roght out toward the jeep without saying another word. The Civilian follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A darkly painted "HUEY" ROARS over low paddies and jungle before emerging onto an open plain. It crosses a barbed wire and sand-bagged perimeter and lands in a heavily fortified, concealed compound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They took me to some place outside Nha Trang... Intelligence Headquarters for all operations in South East Asia. I'd worked for Intelligence before -- Armed men jump from the Huey -- among them Willard. A large camouflaged cover is moved, revealing an undergroun corridor -- they enter.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERGROUND PLOTTING ROOM
dialogues.text: A door swings wide -- Willard steps through and comes to attention, blocking the view of the room. A strange reddish light pervades. The room is covered with plastic maps and filled with smoke. The whole place has been hewn out of the ground itself and there is a sense of the cut-back jungle growth slowly reclaiming it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain B.L. Willard, G-4 Headquarters, reporting as ordered, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Willard, sit down. Willard sits in a chair that is set in a center of a bare concrete floor. Across from him, around steel desks and tables sit several men. The nearest one, a COLONEL puts his cigar out on the bottom of his shoe -- behind him sits a MAJOR and a seedy-looking CIVILIAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever seen this officer before, Captain Willard ? He points to the Major.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This gentleman or myself ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe on your last job you executed a tax collector in Kontum, is that right ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not presently disposed to discuss that, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good. He turns to the Colonel and nods his approval. The Colonel gets up and goes to a large plastic map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know much about about Special Forces; Green Berets, Captain ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've worked with them on occasions and I saw the movie , sir. The officer smiles at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you can appreciate Command's concern over their -- shall we say 'erratic' methods of operation. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have never favored elite units, Captain, including your paratroopers or whatever. Just because a man jumps out of an airplane or wears a silly hat doesn't give him any priviliges in my book -- not in this man's army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We didn't need 'em in Korea -- no sir, give me an Ohio farm boy and an M-1 Garand, none of this fancy crap -- no sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stopping him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have Special Forces A detachments all along the Cambodian border. Two here and another one here -- twelve or fourteen Americans -- pretty much on their own; they train and motivate Montagnard natives; pick their own operations. If they need something, they call  for it, and get it within reason. What we're concerned with is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The A detachment at Nu Mung Ba. It was originally a larger base, built up along the river in an old Cambodian fortress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The area has been relatively quiet for the past two years -- but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Captain, we know something's going on up there -- Major -- The Major looks at some papers in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Communications naturally dwindled with the lack of V.C. activity, this is routine, expected ... but six months ago communication virtually stopped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About the same time -- large numbers of Montagnards of the M'Nong descent began leaving the area -- this in itself is not unusual since these people have fought with the Rhade Tribe that lived in the area for centuries. But what is unusual is that we began to find Rhade refugees too -- in the same sampans as the M'Nongs. These people aren't afraid of V.C. They've put up with war for twenty years -- but something is driving them out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We communicate with the base infrequently. What they call for are air strikes, immediate -- always at night. And we don't know what or who the air strikes are called on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, no one has really gone into this area and come back alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why me ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter Kurtz, Lieutenant Colonel, Special Forces. We understand you knew him. He puts Kurtz' dossier in Willard's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's commanding the detachment at Nu Mung Ba. The Colonel gets up and walks over to a tape recorder, flicks it on. The recording is first STATIC -- the AIR CONTROLLER then asks for more information on target coordinates -- it all sounds very routine, military. Then a frantic VOICE comes on, talking slurred, like someone dumb, except very fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up 2 -- 0 -- give it to me quick -- Mark flare -- affirmative damn -- Immediate receive -- hearing automatic weapons fire man ... GUNFIRE is HEARD and a lower, slower VOICE in background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Delta five This Big Rhine -- three Need that ordinance immediately Goddamn give it to me immediate Christ -- Big Rhino -- Blue God -- Delta damn -- goddamn. A heavy BURST of AUTOMATIC WEAPONS FIRE -- INSANE LAUGHTE -- STATIC, and faintly, very faintly we HEAR HARD ROCK MUSIC -- more STATIC -- suddenly a low, clear VOICE peaceful and serene, almost tasting the words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Big Rhino six -- Blue Delta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Colonel Kurtz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want that napalm dropped in the trees -- spread it among the branches. We'll give you a flare -- an orange one -- bright orange. (STATIC)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd also like some white phosporous, Blue Delta. White phosporous, give it to me. STATIC interrupts -- the Major turns the machine off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only met Kurtz once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would he remember you ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was your impression of him ? Willard shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone got a cigarette. The Major offers him one; they wait as he lights up, thin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought he was a lame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lame ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is years ago, before he joined Special Forces, I guess. We had an argument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. He was a lame, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He couldn't get through a sentence without all these big words; about why we kill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he's killing now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's not Kurtz. I don't believe he's capable of that. I just don't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's got to be Kurtz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The point is that Kurtz or somebody attacked a South Vietnamese Ranger Platoon three days ago. Last week a Recon helicopter was lost in the area -- another took heavy damage -- direct fire from their base camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our Recon flight ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Touchy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can see, of course, the implications, if any of this -- even rumours leaked out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to clean it up -- simple and quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly -- you'll go up the Nung River in a Navy P.B.R. -- appear at Nu Mung Ba as if by accident, re-establish your acquintance with Colonel Kurtz, find out what's happened -- and why. Then terminate his command.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terminate ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terminate with extreme prejudice.

dialogues.speaker: FULL VIEW
dialogues.text: A waterway leading out to the ocean -- it is broken and divided into hundreds of channels, islands, water farms. A Navy patrol boat (P.B.R.) is waiting by a dock area. This is small, light craft, very fast, and heavily armed. Its men stand at attention in a small and simple military ceremony. Willard approaches them in battle- dress: Tiger suit, full field pack, forty-five, helmet, M-16. The boat commander salutes Willard.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: We hear the introductions faintly, UNDER Willard's VOICE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I met the P.B.R. crew; they were pretty much all kids, except for Phillips, the Chief -- Gunner's Mate Third Class L. Johnson -- Lance Johnson; Gunner's Mate Third Class J. Hicks -- The Chef -- Radio Operator Second Class T. Miller; they called him Mr. Clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chief, try to keep out of where we're going -- Why we're goin' and what's gonna be the big surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right with me, I used to drive a taxi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go. The Chief nods.  They all break formation and jump aboard and otherwise go about their work. The twin diesels kick up -- and t he boat moves away from the dock. The Chef jumps aboard; Lance mans the forward twin fifty-caliber machine guns -- they wave to the guard on the dock and move away into the complexity that leads to the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: FULL VIEW
dialogues.text: The boat slams through the heavy sea ; hurtling off the top of a wave and crashing full into the trough of anothe

dialogues.speaker: BOAT COCKPIT
dialogues.text: Willard holds on to whatever he can -- he looks very pale Water crashes over the bow and drenches everyone. The Chief mans the wheel and the ENGINES WHINE. Lance climbs back from his position. He looks at Willard, who just stares ahead into space, swallowing.

dialogues.speaker: BOAT DUSK
dialogues.text: The dusk is spectacular through the broken storm clouds - the sea is calm again.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE BOAT
dialogues.text: The Chief is at the helm -- Willard approaches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Delta closes off to us about ten  miles out of Hau Fat. We'll be able to pick up some supplies -- bit I think there are only two points we can draw enough water to get into the Nung River. It's all Charlie's turf from there on out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna have some help to get in the river. You know these waters, Chief ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bout six months ago I took a man up to Lo Mung Bridge. He was regular Army too. Shot himself in the head. I brought his body  back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shot himself. What for ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beats me -- the sun was too much for him, or the mud. Who knows ? Pause, looking at Willard.

dialogues.speaker: ON WILLARD
dialogues.text: Suddenly, his attention is diverted -- there is a slow buffeting, as if the air around them is being sucked out and replaced quickly. The boat shakes slightly. There is a distant ROLLING NOISE like interrupted thunder. All the men have stopped whatever they're doing -- stand up and look out toward the shore and the green jungle hills beyond. The buffeting and NOISE CONTINUES -- they all stand silently -- suddenly it stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arch light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate that -- Every time I hear that noise something terrible  happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody see some smoke ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too far inland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There they are. He points up to the sky.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SKY
dialogues.text: Way up -- past any clouds and barely discernible, we SEE the black silhouttes of four B-52 bombers, their vapor trails streaming white against the dark blue sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie don't ever hear 'em. Not till it's too late -- don't have to hit you neither, concussion'll do it for a quarter mile or better. Burst your ears -- suck the air outta your lungs.

dialogues.speaker: BOAT
dialogues.text: They are looking up. Willard sits down, unconcerned. He takes out the dossier given him by ComSec. He flips through the letters and other documents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dossier on A detachment had letters from Kurtz' wife and the wives and families of his men. All asking where to send future mail, understanding the necessery silence due to the nature of their work -- None of the men had written home in half a year. Occasionally, in the b.g., we FEEL the terrifying buffeti of the distant B-52 BOMBING.

dialogues.speaker: ON WILLARD
dialogues.text: studying, examining a report.

dialogues.speaker: PICTURES OF KURTZ
dialogues.text: Kurtz' face evolves through the various stages of his career as represented in the pictures in the dossier, as Willard reads :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Kurtz has shown a dedicated and well-disciplined spirit. He is a fine officer, combining military efficiency -- with a broad background in the Humanities, the Arts and Sciences ... Another picture of Kurtz in Germany, standing next to the 161st Petroleum Supply Group sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... He views his military career as the dedication of his talents to bringing our values and way of life to those darker, less fortunate areas in the world. A SHOT of Kurtz at jump school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I feel Captain Kurtz' request for Special Forces training is highly unusual in regard to his past humanitarian concerns, and his somewhat liberal politics, though I can see no reason to deny it. A CLOSE SHOT of Kurtz with Green Beret on in the Vietnam jungle. His face is blank and vacant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... We feel Major Kurtz' need to bring a sense of Western culture to the backward peoples of these areas will be of use in accordance with our 'Vietnamization' programs ... MOVE IN TO Kurtz' empty eyes until the photograph is just a BLURRED MASS OF DOTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One day later we came to an advanced staging area along the coast. This was our last chance to pick up supplies before approaching the mouth of the Nung River.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The VIEW OF THE COASTLINE leading up along the long load- ing docks at Hau Fat, an advance staging area for opera- tions "Brute Force" and "Mailed Fist." Everywhere are tents -- oil drums -- sandbagged bunkers - helicopters -- tanks -- guns -- men. Nobody builds advanced staging areas like the Americans. As the P.B.R. approaches the docking area, Lance notices something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. They look as a Chris-craft speeds by pulling a fancy wate skier who waves as he slaloms by. The men just look at one another.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE DOCK
dialogues.text: The P.B.R. pulls in -- the men scan the busy surroundings

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance -- I want you to go with the Captain an' get three extra drums of fuel and maybe scrounge some more 50 caliber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- look at those uniforms.

dialogues.speaker: PARADE GROUNDS
dialogues.text: A platoon drills in the hot, lazy sun; they are clean and pale, in contrast to Lance and the others, just off the airplane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor bastards, have a long year to go. The troops turn and march TOWARD US with six weeks of Advanced Infantry Training to back them up.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: They are tying up at the dock -- a young SERGEANT is fill ing cut papers concerning them and talking with Willard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know anything about these papers, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're in order -- it's perfectly clean -- just check with ComSec- Intel like I said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you know I don't have the priority to do that, sir. It says here not to contact Com-Sec- Int. Who's your commanding  officer ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now -- I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well who the hell verifies that ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. He signs it quickly, leaving the Sergeant totally confuse

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shit -- what's all the activity for around here ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The show --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What show ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big show in the parade grounds this noon -- some boss stuff --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This -- Bob Hope or the like --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir, I think -- this'll be a little bit different --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's it gonna be ? He points --

dialogues.speaker: PARADE GROUNDS
dialogues.text: A large, well-built pedestal has been erected -- this is surrounded by a deep moat filled with punji stakes and garnished with concertina wire. It is empty --

dialogues.speaker: PARADE GROUNDS
dialogues.text: The entire area around the pedestal and right up to the wire is mobbed with seething American fighting men. Some of these boys have just gotten here -- others have been i the jungle for months. All have one thing in common, to see and if possible grab an American girl. Their need far surpasses that of the run-of-the-mill rapist, pervert, or child-molester. To counter their need of course are the moat, punji stakes and barbed wire -- but implementin this are seven "riot control positions" equipped with the lastest in teargas launchers, attack-trained German shep- herds and assorted psychological warfare aides. Even so armed, the great mass of wild men are right up to the wir

dialogues.speaker: FORWARD AREA
dialogues.text: jammed in the crowd

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's really too much -- I mean I've collected every picture of her since she was Miss December.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- you can really get hung up on them like the cat in the Delta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What cat  ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One that went up for murder -- he was an Army Sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never heard about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- he really dug his Playboy mag, man -- I mean like he was there when it arrived -- He just knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what happened ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was working A.R.V.N. patrols and had one a them little cocky gook asshole Lieutenants -- anyhow, the Lieutenant took his new Playboy one day, sat on the end of the dock, and wouldn't give it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- typical A.R.V.N.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then went too far -- he sat there and starts mutilating the centerfold. Poking pins in her an' all that. Sergeant says, don't do her like that. You leave your shitty little hands off that girl. Gook Lieutenant says Fuck you in Vietnamese -- Sergeant says, don't do that again. You'll wish you hadn't. Then he stood up, flicked his iron to rock and roll and gave the little zero a long burst through the Playboy mag. Man, it blew him clean off the dock -- Hell, just the magazine was floatin' there all full of holes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They nail him for it bad ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in the L.B.J. -- didn't give him no medals or nothing -- In the b.g., we begin to HEAR a SWELL of TWO THOUSAND MALE VOICES; the ENGINES of four helicopters approaching. All heads turn skywards while one descends onto the pedestal kicking up a lot of dust and general resentment. On the nose amd doors of the black Huey are painted large Playboy rabbits. Finally the blades are trimmed and a strange silence descends over the men. The door of the copter slides partially open -- two young Green Berets step out with M-16's to varied catcalls. When this abates a young, extremelly well-dressed man emerges. He is the epitome of a Hollywood AGENT. Hair is combed impeccably and free of dandruff -- clothes are formal but hip -- shoes are shined -- Quite some dude -- his presence causes some stirring but seems to strangely quiet the man. He walks over to the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to say hello from all of us up here, to all of you out there. All of you who've worked so hard during Operation Brute Force -- Paratroopers -- Infantry -- Airmen -- Medics -- Marines -- and Sailors. And I want you to know that we feel proud of you and know how hard your job is. To prove it -- we've brought some entertainment we think you're gonna like: The Playmate of the Year and her two runners up ! He pulls open the door and three unbelieveably beautiful sex playmates in fringed go-go outfits leap out and start dancing to the Creedence Clearwater Revival singing "Suzy Q."

dialogues.speaker: THE GIRLS AND MEN
dialogues.text: VARIOUS SHOTS as the girls dance in an incredibly erotic manner -- smiling. The faces of the G.I.'s pass -- their jaws drop -- some look almost horrified. Chef is hypnotized -- Mr. Clean cries. Chief mouths unspoken obscenities with sentimental tenderness. Others grab the air in front of them. With each movement their need increases by the square.

dialogues.speaker: PEDESTAL
dialogues.text: They crush forward starting to scream -- men fall on the wire -- the guards in the "riot control positions" forget -- the attack dogs are trampled. The mob as one surges forward onto the wire. Men scream and fall into the moat, which is filling up fast. The Agent sees this all as he has seen it before. He casually pulls the pin of a smoke grenade; the girls retreat into the copter -- he follows, then the two Green Berets. The ROTARS WHINE -- the black Playboy Huey lifts off just as the first crazed men reach it. They grab frantically for the wheels, but miss. The Huey wheels up into the blue sky, leaving them all below. Such are the ways of war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The P.B.R. moving further up the primitive coastline. There are few signs of civilization; no villages, no boats -- just the overwhelming presence of the jungle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two days out of Hau Fat, there was nothing but us and the coastline. I felt like I had set off for the center of the earth... Suddenly, Chief looks out, ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoke !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where ? They all turn. Chief points up the coast.

dialogues.speaker: THE COASTLINE
dialogues.text: A thick train of black smoke rises from the green jungle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black smoke ... secondary burning. The Chief grabs field glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- fishing village -- helicopters over there. Hueys, lots of 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First Air Cavalry. They're the ones gonna get us into the River.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEACH AND VILLAGE
dialogues.text: A vast field of devastation -- smashed and smoking palm trees -- deep, ragged craters -- gutted and burning huts -- shattered sampans and bodies washing around in the surf.

dialogues.speaker: BEACH
dialogues.text: They wade through the water to the beach where they are met by a heavily armed group of men. Overhead jets swoop by FIRING ROCKETS, the NOISE drowning out Willard's attempt at conversation with some of the me We can't hear any of the talk, but we notice that the Sergeant turns up to a particular Huey, and points to it.

dialogues.speaker: HELICOPTERS
dialogues.text: Three Hueys swoop in low -- they are heavily laden with machine guns -- rockets and loudspeakers. The two out- side copters hover, while the center copter lands, raisin a lot of dust. It cuts its rotors and the other copters pull up and off to the side. Two armed soldiers jump from the doors and stand with guns ready. Then a tall, strong looking man emerges. He wears a well-cut and neatly-stretched tiger suit. It is COLONEL WILLIAM KILGOR -- tough looking, well-tanned, with a black mustache. He crouches over, holding his hat in the rotor wash. It is no ordinary hat but a L.A. Dodgers baseball hat. He walks out, and then stards to his full immense height and with his hands on his hips he surveys the field of battle His eyes are obscured by mirror-fronted sunglasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bellowing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant: Bomb that tree line back about a hundred yards -- give me some room to breathe. A Lieutenant and radio man nod and rush off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was not quite prepared for this.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON KILGORE
dialogues.text: turning to his GUARDS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring me some cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Body cards, you damn fool -- cards ! The soldier rushes over and hands him two brand new packages of playing cards wrapped in plastic. Two other soldiers get out of the copter and walk over. They are well-tanned and carry no weapons. They seem more casual about the Colonel than anyone else. The Sergeant walks up, leading Willard, the Chief and Lance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (formally)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain B-L. Willard, sir -- 4th Recon Group -- I carry priority papers from Com-Sec Intelligence 11 Corp -- I believe you understand the nature of my mission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- Na Trang told me to expect you -- we'll see what we can do. Just stay out of my way till this is done, Captain. He cracks the plastic wrapping sharply -- takes out the deck of new cards and fans them. The Colonel strides right past Willard with no further acknowledgement. The others follow,

dialogues.speaker: VIEW
dialogues.text: The Colonel walks through the shell-pocked field of devastation. Soldiers gather around smiling; as Kilgore comes to each V.C. corpse he drops a playing card on it -- carefully picking out which card he uses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six a spades -- eight a hearts -- Isn't one worth a Jack in this whole place. The Colonel goes on about this business.

dialogues.speaker: KILGORE
dialogues.text: moving through the corpses, dropping the cards. On of the two tanned soldiers rushes up and whispers something to him. He stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What ? Here. You sure? The soldier points to Lance, who immediately puts down the card he was holding. Kilgore strides over to the young man, who almost instinctively moves closer t Willard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name, sailor ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gunner's Mate, Third Class -- L. Johnson, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance Johnson? The surfer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, sir. Kilgore smiles -- sticks out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an honor to meet you Lance. I've admired your nose-riding for years -- I like your cutback, too. I think you have the best cutback there is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can cut out the sir, Lance -- I'm Bill kilgore -- I'm a goofy foot.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON WILLARD
dialogues.text: His entire, top priority  mission has been put in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Mike from San Diego and Johnny from Malibu -- they're good solid surfers -- none of us are anywhere near your class, though. Lance blushes, sort of mumbling thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My orders are from Com-Sec Intel -- B.L. Willard, 4th Recon --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just hold up a second, Captain -- I'll get to you soon enough -- We've got things to do here. Willard eats it, for now. Kilgore puts his hand on Lance's shoulder, and continues flipping the cards in- discriminately on the bodies as they talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... we do a lot of surfing around here. Like to finish up operations early and fly down to Vung Tau for the evening glass. Have you ever surfed the point at Vung Tau? I liked the beach breaks around Na Trang a lot -- good lefts. He passes a twisted gun emplacement with about five bodies -- sprinkles cards all over them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... we keep three boards in my Command Huey at all times. You never can tell when you're gonna run into something good. I got a guy in Cam Rau Bay that can predict a swell two days in advance. We try to work it in. He stops at a particularly wild-looking Viet Cong who has died with his mouth agape -- staring wild-eyed in horror at the sky. Kilgore pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, that's an Ace if I ever saw one. He puts the card in the gaping mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We SEE the Colonel and the others walk off -- the dead Viet Cong and card are in the immediate f.g. The card has the shield of the CAV printed bautifully, and above it the motto: DEATH FROM ABOVE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where've you been riding, Lance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't surfed since I got here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's terrible -- we'll change  that -- I'd like to see you work -- I've always liked your cutback; got a hell of a left turn, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard is sitting with Kilgore on acouple of chairs by a table set up in front of the command copter. Everywhere we SEE armed men, sandbags, barbed wire, oil drums etc. Hueys are constantly ROARING over. ARTILLERY BOOMS in the far distance. Kilgore looks at the map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why the hell you wanna go up to Nu Mung Ba for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got bored in Saigon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the furthest you been in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haiphong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haiphong? Shit, you jump in ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Walked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you do for supplies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercenaries -- agents, traitors -- they put out caches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you trust them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. They put out two or three for every one I needed. When you get to the one you'll use, you just stake it out. If something feels wrong, you just pass it up. On one mission, I had to pass up three and ended up living on rats and chocolate bars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nu Mung Ba. Last I heard, Walter Kurtz commanded a Green Beret detachment at Nu Mung Ba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did you hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bout a year ago? Is Kurtz still alive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seems to me he got himself fragged. i heard some grunt rolled a grenade in his tent. Maybe a rumor. Helluva man -- remarkable officer. Walter Kurtz woulda been a General some day. General of the Army. Shit, Head of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Did you knew Kurtz?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I met him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you agree?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He musta changed ! (pointing to the map)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to get into the Nung River, here or here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That village you're pointing at is kinda hairy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hairy ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean it's hairy -- they got some pretty heavy ordnance, boy -- I've lost a few recon ships in there now and again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? I heard you had a good bunch of killers here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I don't intend to get some of them chewed up just to get your tub put in the mouth of the goddman Nung River. You say you don't know Kurtz?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I met him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You talk like him. I don't mind taking casualties, Captain, but I like to keep my ratio ten to one in this unit -- ten Cong to one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll find enough Cong up there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about this point here? He puts his finger on the map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the name of that goddamn village -- Vin Drin Dop or Lop; damn gook names all sound the same. He motions to one of his surfers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike, you know anything about the point at Vin Drip Drop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boss left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's really long left slide, breaks on the short side of the point -- catches a south swell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice. Willard looks at Lance -- then at Kilgore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why the hell didn't you tell me about that place -- a good left. (to Willard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There aren't any good left slides in this whole, shitty country. It's all goddamn beach break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hairy ,though. That's where we lost McDonnel -- they shot the hell out of us. It's Charlie's point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How big it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six to eight feet. Kilgore gazes out across the parked helicopters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A six-foot left. Willard nudges Lance -- who gets the idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boss. What's the wind like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light off shore -- really hollow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could go in tomorrow at dawn -- there's always off-shore wind in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The draft of that river might be too shallow on the point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, we'll pick your boat up and lay it down like a baby, right where you want it. This is the Cav boy -- airmobile. I can take that point and hold it as long as I like -- and you can get anywhere you want up that river that suits you, Captain. Hell, a six foot left. (he turns to an advisor)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take a gunship back to division -- Mike, take Lance with you -- let him pick out a board, and bring me my Yater Spoon -- the eight six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, sir -- it's -- it's --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I mean it's hairy in there -- it's Charlie's point. Kilgore turns and looks to Willard, exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie don't surf.

dialogues.speaker: HELICOPTERS
dialogues.text: What seems like hundreds of Hueys standing, their rotors churning a great wind -- Inside, the men of the 1st Cavalry Airmobile -- toughest unit in Vietnam. Kilgore's helicopter is being loaded with ammunition and has surfboards strapped underneath.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: Kilgore strides up to the side door, dressed for battle. He looks out, around. He turns to his door GUNNER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you feel, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a mean motherfucker, sir. He turns to his R.T. man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: FULL VIEW
dialogues.text: Helicopter rotors build up speed -- gas turbines belching fire from their jet pipes -- dust flying as fifty helicopters rise; ROAR OVER CAMERA and deploy into attack formation.

dialogues.speaker: NEW VIEW
dialogues.text: Helicopters moving THROUGH the FRAME: almost a dance of dragonflies.

dialogues.speaker: OTHERS
dialogues.text: Willard looks ahead -- Kilgore sits near the door. Below they see the jungle whisk by and they are suddenly over the ocean, low and fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOTS of rocket pods -- mini-guns in bizarre looking mounts. CLOSE SHOTS of the three surfboards strapped below the command helicopter, next to the fearsome weaponry. And finally, CLOSE SHOTS of the men -- nervous, excited very few of them really scared -- they fondle their rifles, grenade launchers, anti-personnel grenades, claymore mines; plastic explosives cord; flame-throwers; M-60 machine guns; expandable rocket launchers; mortars and bayonets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kilgore cranes his neck and almost leans out to watch the waves -- then he sits back relaxed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Willard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll come in low out of the rising sun -- We'll put on the music about  a mile out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Classical stuff -- scares the hell out of the slopes -- the boys love it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POV behind the PILOT and CO-PILOT -- the ocean rushes below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big Duke six to Eagle Thrust -- turn on coordinates 1-0 -- niner, assume attack formation. The helicopter banks into a tight turn and bears toward the coast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eagle Thrust formation target 2800 yards -- begin psch-war operations.

dialogues.speaker: LOUDSPEAKERS
dialogues.text: The ocean rushes below as suddenly the LOUDSPEAKERS BLARE out Wagner's "Ride of the Valkyries."

dialogues.speaker: HELICOPTERS
dialogues.text: From the water we SEE the massive grouping of Hueys -- gu ships -- troop carriers -- medevac and recon -- ROAR over low in battle formation BLARING out "Ride of the Valkyrie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POV behind pilot --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 700 -- 600 yards -- 500 -- Commence firing. The whole copter shakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Vietnamese coastal fishing village built along the beach and palm trees -- with rice paddies behind. This village commands a delta where ocean and river merge. Sampans are pulled into a cover where they are being unloaded. We SEE bunkers with N.V.A. regulars ambling about. Suddenly we HEAR the distant MUSIC -- Everyone stops; they stare out to see. Men scream orders -- women run from huts bearing ammunition and rifles -- Everywhere there is activity to prepare for the defense of the village. Camouflage is removed from anti-aircraft emplacements. People feverishly unlimber weapons of all types and run to tunnels and trenches. The MUSIC GROWS LOUDER with the FAINT SOUND of ROTORS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: coming directly at us; WAGNER BLARING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: looking down through the helicopters as they approach the village.

dialogues.speaker: CREW
dialogues.text: POV behind pilot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 700 yards -- 600 -- 500 -- commence firing. The whole copter shakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We SEE rockets ROAR from pods -- MACHINE GUNS RATTLE -- grenade launchers POUND away -- and MINI-GUNS pour streams of lead and tracers with the SOUND of a DIESEL HORN.

dialogues.speaker: HELICOPTERS
dialogues.text: POV behind lead gunship. They ROAR in over the beach streaming FIRE from doors, pods and nose -- The ground is alive with smoke and fire -- a hut EXPLODES. The leads ship banks sharply up over the trees -- men run below SHOOTING back.

dialogues.speaker: ANTI-AIRCRAFT EMPLACEMENT
dialogues.text: EXPLOSIONS crash around -- the MUSIC and SOUND of the COPTERS almost drown them out. The gunner FIRES frantically -- COPTERS are ROARING over -- GUNFIRE rips around. The gunner is blown away.

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD
dialogues.text: as the ship he is in swoops down, its MACHINE GUNS FIRING into the village.

dialogues.speaker: SWOOPING COPTER
dialogues.text: The Pilot leans out and SHOOTS a charging V.C. in the head with his .38, then ducks back in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're down, Eagle Thrust -- we're hit. We got a hot L.Z. here. BULLETS RIP through the plexiglass. The Pilot FIRES back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell of a hot L.Z. Need immediate air strike on the tree line, Eagle Thrust.

dialogues.speaker: OTHERS
dialogues.text: Kilgore has R.T. equipment -- he leans out near the door gunner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big Duke Six to Hell's Angels Four -- bring it in on along tree line and huts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell's Angels Four to Big Duke Six -- we'll need green smoke -- suggest you have the FAC mark it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't got time, Hell's Angels -- lay it right up the tree line.

dialogues.speaker: JET SQUADRON
dialogues.text: Four F-4H Phantoms peel off and streak toward the coast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking savages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The enemy. Who else?

dialogues.speaker: THE JETS
dialogues.text: The jets streak by below laying in huge gobs of orange napalm along the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on radio)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good, Hell's Angels -- suggest you follow with cannon fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They circle the battle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Baker Delta Four -- Captain hit bad -- need dust-off. Receiving heavy automatic weapons fire from huts about thirty yards to our left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big Duke Six to Baker Delta Four -- hold -- we're right over you. He turns to door gunner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right along the doors, boy. The gunner FIRES leaning out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine... fine... little higher. Through the roof; yeah, that's good. He leans back in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't anybody bring me any bombs, grenades, claymores or anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't tell me to, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grumbling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shoulda known. Suddenly, BULLETS SMASH through the copter -- Plexiglass SHATTERS; the copter vibrates and turns sharply. Kilgore is thrown down where he hangs on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonuvabitch -- anybody hurt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Automatic weapons flashes along those trees -- probably eleven millimeter guns and AK-47's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trees, eh... He grabs the R.T.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eagle Thrust Four -- Big Duke Six. Join me in sparaying some trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Affirmative, Big Duke Six -- We're even got some rockets left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take her in low, Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: THE TREES, HELICOPTERS
dialogues.text: The two helicopters swoop up out of the smoke and blast the trees with ROCKETS, MACHINE GUNS and GRENADE LAUNCHER Other copters join -- The V.C. break and run through the rice paddies in the f.g. -- BULLETS EXPLODING around them -- they scream and fall FIRING back.

dialogues.speaker: KILGORE, WILLARD
dialogues.text: Kilgore looks out as three V.C. break and run through the rice paddies -- the helicopter turns and follows them -- the door gunner swings out and BLASTS two of them into the mud. He takes a bead on the third.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it, boy. He puts his arms across the sights -- the gunner swings back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take her up to 300 feet, Lieutenant. They rise above the paddy -- the man below runs for all he's worth. Kilgore motions to the door gunner who steps aside. Kilgore buckles himself into the gunner's harness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rifle. A hand passes him a M-16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; hard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My rifle, soldier. There is some fumbling and then a hand passes him a 300 Weatherby Magnum with a zebra wood stock -- mother of pea inlays and a variable power scope. Kilgore takes it and opens the bolt.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON WILLARD
dialogues.text: Amazed at these proceedings.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON KILGORE
dialogues.text: as he loads the rifle with huge cartridges. He gets into the sling and slams the bolt shut. 73  MOVING POV. ON THE V.C. He is running hard, but starting to sink into the mud. The Huey DRONES overhead, its huge shadow behind him on the mud. He turns and FIRES with a pistol.

dialogues.speaker: KILGORE, WILLARD
dialogues.text: Kilgore leans out; pulls the gun in tight -- takes careful aim and the Cong is BLASTED flat into the paddy. Kilgore leans back, opens the bolt, ejecting the spent cartridge out the door. He hands Weatherby back into the copter.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON WILLARD
dialogues.text: The gaudy rifle passed by him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's 27, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone got a card? Somebody hands Willard the deck. He takes a card and flips it out of the copter, never lifting his gaze from Kilgore.

dialogues.speaker: BATTLEFIELD
dialogues.text: Americans run through the hooches FIRING and throwing GRENADES. Helicopters swoop overhead -- JETS ROAR by -- Uniformed N.V.A. regulars burst from a tunnel en- trance and charge the Americans. The SHOOTING is at point blank range -- automatic, as the V.C. are cut down. 77  INT. COMMAND COPTER - KILGORE, WILLARD, LANCE, ETC. Kilgore leans out carefully, looking over the battle- field. He has the R.T. He leans back, deliberately avoiding Willard to speak to Lance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The L.Z.'s cooling off fast -- we'll move in another company an' then we'll own it. (he laughs to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie's point. He looks out toward the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good swell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said it's a good swell -- hell of a good swell 'bout six feet. Let's get a look at it. Lance looks at Willard and then agrees.

dialogues.speaker: COPTER, SURF
dialogues.text: The pilots are used to this -- they bank sharply and swoop in on the lineup of waves, coming in  low over the point and streaking down a long, lined-up green wall as if surfing it. They tip up over and up at the last minute as the wave breaks.

dialogues.speaker: BEACH HUTS, SOLDIERS
dialogues.text: Americans line up blindfolded Viet Cong and N.V.A. regular troops outside a burning hut. GUNFIRE is DISTANT and sporadic -- an occasional MORTAR round SCREAMS in. A soldier yells in Vietnamese in a southern accent and the prisoners are marched away. Other soldiers are already setting up heavy weapons emplacements -- 50 cal machine guns etc. Three Hueys ROAR in, fanning the smoke with their wind. The center one, the command ship, lands. JETS SCREAM over and the two gunships pull up at 200 feet. Another Huey zooms in low and lands behind the Colonel's. The doors open, guards jump out, check the situation, and out steps Kilgore and Lance. From the other copter are more guards, Kilgore's surfers and others of the P.B.R. crew. Willard follows.

dialogues.speaker: THE POINT
dialogues.text: They stride out across the debris-strewn beach. Kilgore stands majestically on the point watching the waves. A SHELL SCREAMS overhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incoming ! They all dive, except Kilgore. He is watching a big set -- the SHELL EXPLODES in the water about a hundred yards away, sending up a huge geyser of spray. Kilgore is unmoved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that. They look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This  L.Z. is still pretty hot, sir, maybe we oughta stand somewhere else. Kilgore pays him no mention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm waiting for the fucking boat, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll get here, soldier. He turns to Mike and Johnny who have their faces in the sand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wh -- what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Change -- get out there -- I want'a see if it's ridable -- change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's still pretty hairy, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bellowing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want'a surf, soldier? He nods yes meakly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good, boy, because it's either surf or fight. They turn and hurry off -- Kilgore grabs an M-1 from one of the guards. They all think he's going to shoot the surfers or someone. They move back uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna cover for 'em -- that's all. He cocks thye weapon. Lance looks around uneasily. The Colonel walks over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think that section on the point is ridable, Lance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we ought to wait for the tide to come in. A SHELL SCREAMS OVER -- they all hit the dirt except for Kilgore. It EXPLODES throwing sand through the air. Kilgore leans down yelling over the NOISE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't happen for six hours. Lance looks up at him terrified, holding onto his helmet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tide -- doesn't come in for six hours.

dialogues.speaker: SURF
dialogues.text: They walk through shallows carrying brightly colored boards. They look very scared. JETS SCREAM overhead, FIRING CANNONS. Helicopters wheel by carrying out wounded. They wear olive drab surfing trunks with the Cav's shield on the left leg. The same shield is emblazoned on the boards along the word "Airmobile". They edge into the water and paddle through the mild shorebreak.

dialogues.speaker: THE POINT
dialogues.text: They paddle up the point in the calm channel -- the beautiful waves breaking beyond them.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY, MIKE
dialogues.text: They paddle on their stomachs, keeping low -- breathing hard and constantly looking around scared out of their minds.

dialogues.speaker: KILGORE AND LANCE
dialogues.text: Kilgore looks at them with his field glasses. Lance kind of sits below taking cover in a shell hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They far enough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure -- fine -- Kilgore turns and takes a giant electric megaphone from a waiting lackey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through megaphone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's far enough -- pick one up and come on in --

dialogues.speaker: THE POINT, SURFERS
dialogues.text: They line themselves up on the point. A good set is building. Mike turns strokes into it -- takes off -- drops to the bottom and turns -- trims up into a tight section -- everything right except he keeps looking around frantically.

dialogues.speaker: LANCE AND KILGORE
dialogues.text: Another SHELL SCREAMS over and EXPLODES down the beach. Lance looks over at Willard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he'll get tubed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he'll get inside the tube -- where -- where they can't see him. A SERIES of SHELLS ROAR in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incoming ! Lance ducks -- puts his hands over his head. The SHELLS SCREAM over Kilgore and out towards the point. Kilgore looks through his glasses -- two EXPLOSIONS in the water are HEARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch. Lance looks up and out toward the point in horror.

dialogues.speaker: THE POINT
dialogues.text: Two surfboards float in the channel bobbing up and down on the waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tragedy of this war is a dead surfer. Willard looks over, beginning to think Lance is crazy, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just something I read in the Free Press.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They just missed a good set -- the chicken shits ! Lance looks up.

dialogues.speaker: THE POINT , SURFERS
dialogues.text: They come up near their boards and climb on -- smoke hangs over the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (megaphone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try it again, you little bastards.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: He turns to Willard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IВґm not afraid to surf this place. I'll surf this place.

dialogues.speaker: KILGORE
dialogues.text: He turns, glowering to his lackeys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring that R.T., soldier. He grabs it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big Duke Six to Hell's Angels -- Goddamit, I want that treeline bombed -- yeah -- napalm -- gimme some napalm -- son of a bitch -- yeah, I'll take H.Z. or C.B.U.'s if you got any of them -- just bomb 'em into the Stone Age, boy. He throws the R.T. back to a soldier -- another SALVO WHISTLES over -- everyone drops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch. As the SHELLS EXPLODES on the beach behind him, KIlgore raises his M-16 and EMPTIES it full automatic in the general direction of the trees. He mumbles a few un- intelligible swear words and jams a new clip into his rifle turning to Lance --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll have this place cleaned up and ready for us in a jiffy, boy. Don't you worry. He FIRES another clip as the JETS SCREAM overhead.

dialogues.speaker: RIVER
dialogues.text: A sky-crane without pod descends slowly toward us -- The P.B.R. hangs below it. The Chief, mr. Clean and Chef stand watching this sight alomg with other soldiers. A man guides the descending copter till the boat settles carefully in the shallows. The Chief and others leap aboard; unshackle the hoists -- load on ammunition and fuel. The battle is still going on around them. They all look up as a wadge of PHANTOMS streak over low and peel off one by one to begin their bombing run.

dialogues.speaker: PHANTOMS
dialogues.text: Phantoms RAKE the trees with 20 mm CANNONS -- FIRE five inch ROCKETS in salvo -- "Bull Pup" MISSILES -- drop H.E. (high explosives) and C.B.U's (Cluster Bomb Units) and finally an immense amount of NAPALM. 94  FULL SHOT ON THE P.B.R. The Chief is at the helm --the engine starts; Clean and Chef work feverishly, ducking for cover every-so- often when an EXPLOSION hits nearby. The boat begins to back out of the shallows. The EXPLOSIONS of NAPALM are reflected on their faces; the ROAR of the FIRE drowns out almost everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget that extra drum -- it's too damn hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clear on starboard -- Where's Lance an' the Captain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw that Colonel's Huey on the point -- Two HELICOPTERS SCREAM over FIRING ROCKETS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just get outta here.

dialogues.speaker: OTHERS
dialogues.text: Kilgore watches the waves with his field glasses -- smoke drifts over. Lance crouches below. Willard is up looking off in anothe direction. SHELLS SCREAM over, but even their noise is drowned out by the fierce SHRIEK of the PHANTOMS and the deafening BLAST of HIGH EXPLOSIVES. Willard stares at the tree line where it comes down to the river. The JETS are making a hell of the tree line; a hell of fire and bust- ling steam thet nothing could live in. Willard's glance goes further downriver through the black smoke and there merging in the river -- small and vulnerable, is his boat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. There it is; the boat. Lance looks over --  a tremendous relief on his face. But still there remains the threat of Kilgore, standing stark against the sky. Willard silently motions Lance toward the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll kill us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't kill us. (realizing as he says it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're on his side. Kilgore FIRES another clip at the tree line, and then strides back without looking at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You smell that. (louder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You smell that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napalm, boy -- nothing else in the world smells like that -- They reflect the glow from the burning trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; nostalgically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love the smell of napalm in the morning.  One time we had a hill bombed for 12 hours. I walked up it when it was all over; we didn't find one of 'em ... not one stinking gook body. They slipped out in the night -- but the smell -- that gasoline smell -- the whole hill -- it smelled like ... (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: victory... He looks off nostalgically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, some day this war's gonna end..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sadly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I know. Suddenly he senses something -- he stops -- lifts his hand -- then frantically licks his fingers and puts them up in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wind --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Sure enough there is a rushing breeze that increases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising maniacally)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feel it -- it's the wind -- it's blowing on shore -- It's on shore ! He leans down and practically grabs Lance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; screaming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gonna blow this place out. It's gonna ruin it ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kid can't ride sloppy waves. They turn and stare out to sea.

dialogues.speaker: THE POINT
dialogues.text: The wind has changed. Instead of blowing spray back over the waves and hollowing them out, this strange wind is causing white caps and cross chop.. reducing the swell to slop. Mike and Johnny lay low on their boards, overjoyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kid can't stand sloppy waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't expect this kid to ride that crap, do you? He's a goddamn artist, he needs something to work with... Slapping Lance on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm an artist, goddamit !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apologetically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- yeah, I can understand how you feel. He turns toward the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the napalm -- it's causing the wind -- ruining my perfect left. He staggers off toward the trees followed by his guards and other lackeys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; mumbling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The napalm -- ruin -- napalm my perfect left -- my perfect left point break -- napalm -- Lance motions with his eyes to Willard. 98  FULL SHOT ON THE P.B.R. The P.B.R. along the river shallows -- The Chief and crew waiting and yelling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you finished surfing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to say goodbye to the Colonel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let's get the hell out of here. They break and run like hell toward the boat in the distance. OUR VIEW TRACKS with them. They are cheered by the crew -- suddenly, Willard sees some- thing and stops... Lance continuing. In a pile of equipment that the Hueys have left are two surfboards -- Willard looks at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- no, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one's the Colonel's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Yater -- the clear one with the thin stringer. Willard glances over to it with determination. There is still MORTAR FIRE coming in between him and the board. Suddenly, Willard makes a run for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incoming ! Incoming -- son of a bitch. The ROUNDS bracket the P.B.R. and line up the beach toward Willard. He stands there and doesn't move, the surfboard under his arm. The shells kick up sand. Lance has dropped. Fragments whistle by, one rips  a chunk of foam and fibreglass from the rain of the board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one , Lance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Jesus Christ ! Once again, Willard takes off fast as hell with the board under his arm. Lance follows toward the boat, through the water. Willard hands the board up to Mr. Clean, and they both scamper abroad, exhausted and relieved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you that for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was a kid I, never had a Yater spoon. Mr. Clean stuffs the board in the stern 50 Cal. mount. The boat turns -- ENGINES RUNNING HARD and ROARS OFF toward the deeper water of the river -- the board clearly visible on the stern.

dialogues.speaker: THE RIVER
dialogues.text: The P.B.R. ROARS BY going down the river at full speed. It is swerving and zig-zagging to avoid potential enemy fire.

dialogues.speaker: THE CREW
dialogues.text: They all are in full battle positions -- their twin fifty Cal. guns turning; warily covering the jungled banks. The Chief is at helm -- Willard crouches against some armor plate, huddled with his M-16 ready. Chef is behind him at the radio. Lance leans back from his forward turret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we better stay in under the trees till dark -- we got his Yater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't look like he'd take that sitting down. They all look up into the sky -- expecting the worst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's put some distance between us and Charlie. The Chief nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you roll us a big joint? I think the Captain'd like that. They all look at Willard uneasily. After a suspensful pause, Willard smiles:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take one a mine -- He fishes into his breast pocket -- pulls out a huge cigar-sized joint. They all smile -- Willard lights up.

dialogues.speaker: THE P.B.R.
dialogues.text: It zig-zags away from us down the river at high speed.

dialogues.speaker: THE TREES, BOAT, CREW
dialogues.text: The boat is hidden under some trees along the river bank. The men wait tensely listening --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hear it again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- I don't think so. But it'll be back. They were circling. It'll be back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think he'd of shot us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any time -- us -- Americans. Lance looks over at Willard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think heВґd of shot us on the beach but -- he'd of shot us if he saw me taking the board --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Yater spoon is hard to get -- especially here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a man who knows what he  wants -- he does know what he wants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I go get those mangos now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go with you in a while -- judt hold tight awhile --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain -- that was all true about the rats and chocolate and stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you could just tell when the supplies were booby trapped?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a feeling you get in the jungle. When you get good, you can find a track and tell not only how many they are, but their morale, how far they're going, whether they're near their camp, the weapons they're carrying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you tell their weapons.. an' how far they're going? Willard smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
