dialogues.text: Mostly from the imprints when they put them down to rest. their morale from the way they drag their feet, or the joints that may be lying around. If they're near a base camp, they wouldn't be conserving food; they'll be throwing it away half-eaten. If the branches aren't broken, their weapons are slung. But all this is just technique.. There's a feeling you get after a while, that's what's important. I was going through a village once. I was looking for a certain party. I took off my boots, and walked into each hut. It was midnight. I went into three like that and suddenly I realized IВґd gone into each hut the same way -- standing up -- so the next one I went in on my belly. An RPD burst took out the door a bit above my head. (he shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things like that. A pause, and then suddenly his attention is diverted -- They all are silent -- It is pitch dark -- we HEAR the distant SOUND of ROTOR-BLADES and indistinguishable language on a loudspeaker -- The talk stops -- the ROTORS grow LOUDER until almost overhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over a loudspeaker)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not gonna hurt or harm you, boy -- I just want the board back -- You can understand -- It was one of my best -- You know how hard it is to get a board you like, boy. I'm not gonna hurt or harm you -- Just leave it where I can find it -- The HELICOPTER DRONES on into the night -- the same speech starts again further off -- Finally the noise ceases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus -- that guy's too damn much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if that was the same copter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's probably got 'em all over the river with that recording. We better move now while it's dark. Chef steps forward with a plastic basket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Chef -- go ahead -- take Lance with you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go with him -- They all look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanta get my feet on solid land once in awhile -- He grabs an M-16 and follows Chef over the side.

dialogues.speaker: THE JUNGLE
dialogues.text: They cautiously walk through the underbrush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chef.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why they call you that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me what, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chef -- is that 'cause you like mangoes an' stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir -- I'm a real chef, sir -- I'm a sauciere --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sauciere --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, sir -- I come from New Orleans -- I was raised to be a sauciere.. a great sauciere. We specialize in sauces; my whole family. It's what we do. I was supposed to go to Paris and study at the Escoffier School; I was saving the money. They called me for my physical so I figured the Navy had better food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing out here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cook school -- that did it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They lined us all up in front of a hundred yards of prime rib -- magnificent meat, beautifully marbled.. Then they started throwing it in these big cauldrons, all of it -- boiling. I looked in, an' it was turning gray. I couldn't stand it. I went into radio school. They move into a slight clearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- quiet -- Chef crouches close -- redies his M-16. Willard ges- tures that he heard something; he points.

dialogues.speaker: DIFFERENT ANGLE
dialogues.text: PAN SLOWLY over jungle -- END REVEALING Willard and Chef.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (silent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There... He points -- motions Chef to move away -- they cover the spot. A few yards from them they hear something move. It is obviously no small jungle creature. They walk toward a patch of black elephant grass; their guns at the ready. They look at each other. Willard is cold, methodical, doing something he knows well. There is a noise again -- some of the growth rustles.  He and Chef move a distance apart, and join in stalking the probable V.C. Willard directs the Chef with hand gestures, and bird and cricket sounds. They move stealthily, closing the apex of their triangle on the hunted. The two men drop low into the elephant grass, and remain motionless. Then Willard makes the cricket noise, and they move closer. Willard's left hand edges out along the M-16's far end, so that he only has to point the finger of that hand and he will hit what he wants. He makes another command and they rush the trapped enemy.

dialogues.speaker: THE ELEPHANT GRASS
dialogues.text: Suddenly there is a RUSHING SOUND -- The grass folds down quickly toward them -- willard plants his feet and from the hip lets go FULL AUTOMATIC. The Chef retreats FIRING short BURSTS into the grass -- the grass folds almost to Willard -- then a huge tiger leaps out at them; snarling magnificently. They FIRE wildly, emptying their clips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a motherfucking tiger -- goddamn... He turns and bolts through the jungle, as scared as a man can be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; screaming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn -- Jesus Christ tiger -- motherfucking tiger -- ohhhhhhhhh -- Willard jams another clip in his gun and backs out of the clearing, covering the bushes and runs, scared out of his head as well.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOAT
dialogues.text: They all are armed -- Lance has the twin 50's pointed int the jungle. Chef comes screaming out of the brush, throws his rifle into the boat and dives headfirst after it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hysterical)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohhhh -- tiger ! Oh goddamn ! It's a tiger ! Jesus Christ ! Goddamn, a tiger ! Ohhhhhhhh. The Chief tries to grab him; takes his gun away, but is unable to take a hold of the Chef, as he slithers around the boat, trying to find safety. willard follows from the jungle -- The Chef is moaning and stares off into the nig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this tiger shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shit... I think I shot the hell out of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasnВґt looking.. I was running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was a big tiger -- no shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who stopped to measure him -- let's get the hell out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A motherfucking tiger -- I could've been killed. The ENGINE ROARS to life -- the P.B.R. pulls away with gr speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You forgot the mangoes, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mangoes? There as a fucking tiger in the woods -- I could've been eaten alive. I'm never going into that jungle again. I gotta remember never get out of the boat; never get outta the boat. They move off; swallowed by the darkness. The JUNGLE  NOISES remain, as OUR VIEW BEGINS a MOVE INTO the jungle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was right, the Chef -- never go into the jungle, unless you're ready to go all the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard, thinking, his BACK TO US. Suddenly, he turns around, and we SEE his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was in the jungle? What was there, waiting for me? He lights the cigarette; the light of his match illuminat his face momentarily. There is something different about him; a maturity, a cool inner peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Kurtz was in there. Or was he; was it Kurtz? He was just a name to me now; I couldn't remember a face, a voice -- he just didn't add up to me. all his liberal bullshit about the end of savagery -- and the role of our culture, our way of life... Willard looks toward the group of people on the boat -- there is still some MUSIC. They talk and drink and laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our way of life -- I really started to look forward to meeting Kurtz again.

dialogues.speaker: WATERWAY
dialogues.text: We HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- must remember that we owe our thanks for these to the wonderful services of the U.S.O. -- here's another oldie -- this one dedicated...

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON CHEF
dialogues.text: by himself on the P.B.R.; he has wiped mud under his eyes to kill the glare; it is incredibly hot. He is barechested, wearing a hat made of a banana palm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... to the fire team at An Khe from their groovy C.O. Fred the Head --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rolling Stones and "Satisfaction..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outa sight. The SONG BLARES ON -- they all dig it. PAN TO Willard, sitting alone in the rear, reading from his file on Kurtz. We REVEAL Lance in the b.g., water- skiing behind the P.B.R., slaloming back and forth on his single ski to the MUSIC -- jumping the wake occasion- ally. 112  NEW VIEW - ON THE P.B.R. Lance waterskiing to "Satisfaction."

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON CLEAN
dialogues.text: alert, at the rear of the boat -- his M-16 ready, just in case.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON WILLARD
dialogues.text: Willard opens a letter from the packet. We can SEE it is a private correspondence -- feminine writing on the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dossier of A Dtachment contained letters from the families and wives of Kurtz' men There were letters from Kurtz' wife as well.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE LETTER
dialogues.text: It is addressed to Colonel Walter Kurtz -- in the corner is the return addess of Mrs. Colonel Walter Kurtz -- Willard's hand fushes through the packet and comes up with apicture of a very attractive, thirty-five year old American Beauty... She is classically American.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: looking at the picture -- puts it back, then opens the letter, straightens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dearest Walt -- I have to confess something. I know how you feel about this, but I had to ask Bob to find out what he could -- I just couldn't stand it anymore, not knowing where you are, whether you're alive or dead. I'm sorry Walt, I'm sorry I said that. Bob didn't tell me anything -- he said he couldn't -- I can't stand it anymore, Walt -- I just can't stand it. Willard looks out at the jungle. Deep imppenetrable jungle -- dark and primeval forests pass by. The Rolling Stones CHANT on in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to take the kids to school every morning now -- carpools just never work out. Jeff came home with a black eye on Tuesday but said he won anyway. He wouldn't tell me what the fight was about. Jeff keeps asking where you are -- he has maps of Viet Nam in his room now. He misses you very much. I can't take this much longer, Walt. I love you and I just can't stand it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD
dialogues.text: He folds the letter up, files through some others quickly and gets to a peculiar envelope stamped Top Secret with a stenciled date on it. It is also noted that this was the last correspondence to leave Nu Mung Ba. It is addressed to Kurtz' wife. He opens the letter -- it is written in a scrawled savage hand to no one in partic- ular. It reads: Sell the house Sell the car Sell the kids Find someone else Forget it I'm never coming back Forget it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He folds up the letter.

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD
dialogues.text: He looks out at the ominous jungled mountains.

dialogues.speaker: P.B.R.
dialogues.text: The P.B.R. pulls in towards an American outpost that is being used as a forward medical evacuation center. Various helicopters pads are SEEN, but only one heli- copter -- the H-34 painted with Playboy rabbits that brought the girls to Hau Fat. Several soldiers in rain- coats come out the dock as the P.B.R. pulls up.

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD, SOLDIERS
dialogues.text: Willard looks into some empty tents -- looks around the dreary muddy camp. Two soldiers pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soldier -- where'Вґs your C.O.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stepped on a booby trap, sir -- got blown all to hell --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well , who's in command here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know -- don't have any idea -- I'm just the night man -- He turns and walks off babbling incoherently --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about you, soldier? The soldier he was talking to turns around smiling idiotically and making animal noises. He stumbles off after his friend.

dialogues.speaker: DIFFERENT ANGLE
dialogues.text: He looks around disgustedly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain -- Willard turns around looking for where the voice came from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over here, Captain -- He turns to see the Hollywood Agent under the flap of a large tent so that he won't get wet. He wears the same clothes as before, but is much dirtier. He motions Willard into the tent.

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD, AGENT
dialogues.text: They duck inside -- it is dark and damp. On cots around astove sit the three playmates and the pilot. The nearest one, CATHY, a blonde, picks leeches out of her feet. The other two, TERRI and LYNDA, play cards with the helicopter pilot. Willard looks over  the situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You came in on that boat, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you headed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it matter? Get to the  point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look -- you know the girls -- Thta's Terri -- she was playmate of --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I caught your show at Hau Fat. They all look over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- I see -- Well, girls, this is Captain -- eh --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Willard -- go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look -- we got in a little trouble -- they rudely took our helicopter for MedEvac work on this -- uh Operation Brute Force -- They just brought it back this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I mean like they also took our fuel -- We've been here two days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dreadful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look -- the girls could get killed -- we're not supposed to be this close combat, I mean real combat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could use some fuel -- just a half drum -- just enough to get us out a here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need all our fuel. He turns and starts to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Captain, think what these girls have done for the boys -- think of how they've risked -- Willard is almost out of the tent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain -- He turns around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's really rough here -- Captain -- we're just not built for it -- The Pilot laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's rich --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do us a favor -- I'd do one for you -- if I could -- Willard just stares at her -- even though she's in jeans and field jacket she is something to see -- The Agent takes Willard aside -- Terri goes back to the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look -- you know who that is, Captain -- you know what she's saying -- you'll never see stuff that good outside of a magazine for the rest of your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not that fond of blondes -- maybe I like brunettes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your pick -- they all like you -- I can tell --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like all of them --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good -- like I said, take your  pick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said I like all of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now just a second -- I'm doing you a favor, buddy -- what're you trying to pull? Willard turns to leave again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need all our fuel anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait -- wait -- don't get up tight -- what I meant was we'd need a whole drum for that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down -- we'll talk about it. Willard sits down on a metal chair -- motions the Agent to do likewise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's there to talk about -- this whole thing disgusts me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My men --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what there is to talk  about -- my man -- I take a good care of my men -- The girls are trying to pretend they're not listening -- the helicopter Pilot is cackling to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're out of your skull --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a lot of pride in our unit --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far do you think you can push -- what kind of people do you think --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Esprit de corps --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- absolutely not --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One for all -- all for one --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can keep your fucking fuel -- Willard gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You make some of your closest friends in the army -- war has a way of bringing men together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men of all races -- nationalities -- He gets up and starts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two drums -- Willard turns around slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two whole drums --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can use some fifty caliber and a 16 too --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're talking about -- Get fucked --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will -- I assure you that -- You got a fifty on that H-34 -- leave the ammo in boxes -- I'll get my men to bring the first drum with 'em -- He turns to go under the tent flap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have the girls freshen up a bit -- comb their hair -- put on something -- you know what I mean -- He leaves.

dialogues.speaker: P.B.R.
dialogues.text: They are all working on patching the boat and cleaning it up in general. Mr. Clean sits in f.g., cleaning an M-1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You keep this thing in this condition an' it's gonna jam, Lance -- mark my words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you go pet the water buffaloes -- get off my back. Behins them on the beach stand several water buffaloes eating mud or whatever they do. They are painted jungle brown and green camouflage with grey bottoms -- on their sides the words have been stenciled in black:  1 Each -- Buffalo, Water B-1A U.S. Army No. 15239

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard walks through them down to the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful,  Captain, they've been known to charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right I got a little surprise for you -- They all look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've arranged with those people we saw at Hau Fat to give us some 50 caliber in trade for a couple a drums of fuel --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chef -- since you're such a fan of Miss December's I think you should be detailed with Lance and Clean to take the first drum up there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you trying to say, Captain --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll see soon enough -- get going, sailor --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shit -- hot damn --

dialogues.speaker: LYNDA, CHEF
dialogues.text: He has followed her into the tent awe-struck -- she casuallu starts unbuttoning her fatigue jacket and taking off her pants. he just stands there, his arms at his sides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got every one of your pictures -- I've got the centerfold -- the Playmate's review -- the Playmate of the Year run-off -- everything, even the calender --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, get undressed and let's get it over with --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe it -- I'd a never even got to see you if it wasn't for this war -- She lies down on the cot in only her panties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't mind -- uh kinda draping that jacket over you sort of the way you were in the calender, would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on -- cut this crap -- I gotta get back to Saigon --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just let me look awhile -- I just don't believe --

dialogues.speaker: LANCE, CATHY
dialogues.text: They have just finished making love. cathy looks very pleased. Lance finishes tying his boots -- she draws on his back. He gets up -- starts to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- uh thanks -- see you around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. He leaves -- she pulls herself up and starts combing her hair -- Mr. Clean walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm next -- She shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD, TERRI
dialogues.text: He finishes tying on his boots -- pulls on his jacket -- his gun belt and picks up his M-16. She looks up at him -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am -- I'd like to thank you for what you an' all your friends have done for us -- I want you to know that me an' the men appreciate you coming all this way -- riskin' your lives -- living uncomfortably an' doing all you can to entertain us. I want you to know personally, Miss, that for the past few minutes you have made me feel at home. She picks up a shoe to throw at him. he turns, exits f.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just wanted to say that, ma'am. The SHOE CLANGS off his helmet.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: The boat edges in toward the wrecked bridge in the distance. Along the banks are sandbagged fortificvations with U.S. soldiers in them. There is a bright fire burning uncontrolled in the distance; the sparks and whit light from welding on the bridge momentarily lights up th night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two days and nights later, we approach the Do Lung Bridge.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE FACES OF THE P.B.R. CREW
dialogues.text: watching. Everywhere are wrecked boats -- parts of trunks sticking out of the water -- smashed helicopters on the banks. The bridge is in a state of siege. Mortars and rockets arc through the night indiscriminately and rip through the nearby jungle. Soldiers are everywhere -- scurrying from trenches, carrying materials for the bridg or tending to the wounded, the maimed and the dead. Light automatic WEAPON FIRE is HEARD occasionally. The P.B.R. edges in under the span of the old bridge. Soldiers run up through the water. They are obscured in the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta get out a here -- IВґll pay -- I got money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get away from this boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's your C.O., soldier? The Soldier ducks back and runs away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you, you'll get what's coming  to you. Other men approach the boat. A young LIEUTENANT steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Willard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Willard -- we got these from Nha Thrang two days ago -- they expected you here then -- He hands up a plastic bag, maximum security markings, Willard takes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know how happy that makes me, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I can get out a here -- if I can find a way out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be needing some supplies and fuel -- do you know anybody who can give me a hand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd just clear out as soon as I could if I were you, sir. They're gonna start working on the bridge with torches again. Charlie will start throwing it in hard --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this bridge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's of strategic importance for keeping the highway into Bat Shan open -- the generals don't like to admit that Bat Shan is surrounded. He points to the men getting ready to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every night we build it and by 0800 they've blown it up -- it and a lot of good men -- But the generals like to say the road is open -- ha ! Nobody uses that road except Charlie. He turns and splashes off into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the cesspool of hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incoming. SHELLS WHISTLE OVER and CRASH into the bridge -- MEN SCRE in the distance -- the EXPLOSIONS are thunderous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right -- Lance, go with the Captain an' see what you can scrounge -- Willard climbs out with Lance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; to Willard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better make it fast, sir -- we don't really need much anyway. Willard nods and they scurry off the bank under the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD, LANCE
dialogues.text: They dash up the embankment and along the barbed wire on the edge of the road. SHELLS SCREAM overhead, they don't know where to run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straight ahead, son of a bitch. They dive towards the voice.

dialogues.speaker: TRENCH
dialogues.text: They dive in, a SOLDIER is crounched in f.g. holding his buddy who is crying uncontrollably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You came right to it, son of a bitch --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch, sir. The Soldier doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your chief supply officer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beverly Hills --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straight up the road -- a concrete bunker -- Beverly Hills -- where else you think he'd be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon -- There is an apparent lull and they dash out along the road. Suddenly to their right an M-60 STARTS OPENING UP from a sandbagged emplacement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get your asses down, buddy. They drop and crawl to the slit trench and run up to the emplacement. Several SOLDIERS man a M-60. One has a sniper rifle -- another tries to spot for the Gunner. Willard and Lance edge up along the trench. Willard trips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch your feet, asshole -- Willard looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stepped on my face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We thought you were dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole world loves a smart ass. They move ahead more carefully. The Gunner BLASTS away into the night, there is a pile of brass cases about thre feet high next to him. Finally he stops swearing to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you shooting at, soldier?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gooks. He turns and sees it's an officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IВґm sorry, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, sergeant -- what's out there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were tryin' to cut through the wire -- I got 'em all I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah -- listen. There is a low moaning SCREAM from out in the wire -- it stops for aminute then continues hideously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's trying to call his friends -- send up a flare. The Spotter does, it arcs up, then bathes them in eerie light. The Gunner FIRES a long BURST.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are all dead, stupid, he's obviously underneath 'em -- They think about this as the flare goes out. The SCREAMIN gets more intense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wake up the Roach. The Spotter moves down to where a tall lanky SOLDIER is leaned up against the trench. He kicks him hard several times. Roach wakes and just looks up. On his helmet are the words: "GOD BLESS DOW."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slope in the wire -- hear him. He listens, he does, he nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bust him. Roach gets up somewhat annoyed but very cool. He saunters up the machine gun dragging his M-79 which has paisley designs all over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure , yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need a flare --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, itВґs cool. He opens the breech of his shotgun-like weapon and plunks the big slug into it. He snaps it closed then rests it across his forearm over the trench -- he listens to the SCREAM, calculating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's close -- real close. He adjusts his sights so that the gun is aimed high into the air. He listens again then FIRES. The GRENADE WHISTLES off into the night. There is a sharp EXPLOSION that cuts off the scream. Then the THUD of bodies or pieces of bodies coming down around them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muhhh Fuhhh ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He staggers back down the trench to go to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: P.B.R.
dialogues.text: They stand in the shallows waiting for Willard and Lance. Clean is nervous, he constantly checks his M-16. SHELLS WHISTLE by and CRASH in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geez, I wish they'd hurry. A SOLDIER comes up on his way with some others to start building the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, buddy, that boat still runs, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it still runs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do me a favor buddy, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? He takes out a handful of crumpled envelopes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send these out when you get back to the world. He puts them in Clean's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's to everyone I really knew -- the first girl I screwed -- my brother -- best friend -- I wanted to tell 'em how much I enjoyed knowing 'em -- it's been a great twenty years. I gotta let 'em know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you askin' me for -- put 'em in the first helicopter comes in tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody comes in here. He points up at the mountain ridges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The N.V.A. 312th -- over there the 307th -- on that hill we counted fourteen different guns in one minute -- they got rockets mortars, snipers in those trees, there's a million of those shitty little bastards out there -- we're all gonna die. He grabs Clean and looks at him with a maniacal urgency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna be dead. Clean takes the letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a chance in that boat -- by morning you could be five miles down the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ain't goin' down the river. The Soldier looks at him as if he is joking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up river from here anyhow -- The Soldier doesn't answer, just stares dumbfounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spooky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it'd be spooky without the war -- give 'em back. He takes the letters and leaves, somewhat disappointed an disgusted. Willard and Lance come back down the beach carrying some belts of ammunition and a couple of extra M-16's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, you must a found the C.O., eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We found some bodies -- let's get out a here. 132  FULL SHOT - DIFFERENT ANGLE - P.B.R. They edge through the shallows as the men light up their welding torches to start work on the pontoon bridge -- then pull away and accelerate fast.

dialogues.speaker: THE P.B.R. CREW
dialogues.text: The Chief is at the helm --  they all look back in the distance where the bridge was -- the hills flash with artillery discharges -- there is a fiery glow from the bridge area and the CONCUSSION of heavy EXPLOSIONS.

dialogues.speaker: P.B.R.
dialogues.text: The boat moves uneasily upriver, through this tropical downpour. Mr. Clean is in thef.g., oiling and cleaning his 50-cal, his M-11 and M-79 -- the rest of the crew are forward, taking shelter from the rain under the canvas canopy. Clean works methodically under an umbrella he was set up by leaning the surfboard against gun mount.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The river is moving fast against them. all manner of de- bris; tree trunks, sweeping by the P.B.R.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Willard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't see a fucking thing. There is a loud CRACKING SOUND, as one of the pieces of tree- trunk whacks the hull, and bounces off. Willard climbs forward, and looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hit a big enough one this hull will shatter like a Corvette. Fucking plastic boat. Willard practically hangs off forward with a long pole, warding off the big debris moving toward the P.B.R. Clean joins him, helping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting to Chief)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about ducking into one of those tributaries till this river slows down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who knows what's up there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't be any worse than this. What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think this river wants to take us home fast. I'm practically goin' in reverse. Willard points his pole in the direction of the mouth of a tributary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, get in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This whole area is lousy with V.C. -- We don't stand a chance. Lemme turn around and we'll be in Hau Fat in six minutes. There is a really loud WHACK against the hull. willard really mad, throws the pole at the Chief, who ducks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in there !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my crew and my fucking boat, and I'm the responsible party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in there now or I'll bury you in this river. It's clear that Willard will kill the Chief if he doesn't do as he says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally relents,  turns the helm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're fucking crazy. You're going to get us all killed. The P.B.R. navigates through the rush and into the mouth of the tributary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain is pouring down, but the P.B.R. is slowed down to a snail's pace by Hyacinths, literally across the waterway. Willard, Chef and Clean in the water, cutting through them with machetes.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON LANCE
dialogues.text: having climbed to the highest point of the cockpit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It breaks through in about twenty feet.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON WILLARD
dialogues.text: cutting through. he looks to Chef, who has stopped cut- ting, and is staring into the jungle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. He looks out -- the jungle at this point is very dark and high -- totally impenetrable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep cutting. They work feverishly, knowing something is wrong.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON CHEF
dialogues.text: cutting with all he's got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it sounds stupid, but I feel like the goddamn jungle's watching us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatdoya think it thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That we're dumber than we look. Chef stops again, looks hard, trying to penetrate the darkness and from the very depth of it -- the darkness of it, comes a stream of tracers, lazily arching out at them It whips between them -- the SOUND FOLLOWING much later. Other BULLETS SMASH through and ricochet off the deck fittings. GLASS SHATTERS, and a huge hunk of paint is removed from the armor shield by a 20 mm cannon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance -- 'bout twenty meters starboard. Lance leaps down to his position. Willard, Clean and Chef cut feverishly, as the trapped boat struggles to get free

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There in the trees ! Everything is confusion -- yelling -- GUNFIRE -- the THUD of heavy BULLETS ripping inti the P.B.R.'s fibreglass hul

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON LANCE
dialogues.text: Lance's twin guns return the FIRE. The Chief moves to one of the heavy guns and joins Lance in returning the FIRE.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE MEN IN THE WATER
dialogues.text: pushing, cutting. Bullets SMASH and EXPLODE around. Clean climbs onto the boat, and leaps onto a gun emplace- ment.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: Nobody really knows where the erratic fire is coming from

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back at the helm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elevate Lance, in the tree. No, I saw another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty meters up, Lance; I saw the fucking flash. Lance grits his teeth, FIRING --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He BLASTS short bursts of tracers into the jungle, cuttin it to salad. Suddenly more tracers from another direction -- Clean swings around -- BULLETS smash against his shiel and rip chunks from the surfboard. He BLASTS a long heavy burst at the jungle -- trees crumble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm ripping 'em, man, son-of-a- bitch, it's jammed, oh God, it's jammed. Clean is riddled by MACHINE GUN FIRE. Chief runs to Mr. Clean -- it is obvious that he is dead. He looks angrily to Willard. Willard and Chef are practically through. Willard leaps up, as Chef finishes the last strokes. He moves toward the cockpit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throw me that ordnance. Chef throws him an M-79 and several shells -- Willard opens it, jams a huge projectile and pulls himself over the edge of the cockpit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me some kind a field a fire -- BULLETS rip by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exhausted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're through. He climbs aboard and collapses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (FIRING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't finished ! I ain't finished !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring that bow ordnance into  those trees. He jams his gun up as he sees a flash and FIRES -- there is a low POP and a WHISTLE as the GRENADE arches into the jungle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He FIRES another burst as the GRENADE EXPLODES brightly. There is another POP and WHISTLE , another BLAST. A large tree falls, just as the craft speeds up through the thin- ning growth. We HEAR strange SCREAMING from the trees and jungle, hideous MOANS and terror-filled CRIES.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHIEF
dialogues.text: He jams the throttle forward -- the boat surges ahead. Willard FIRES another GRENADE from his M-79. 147  FULL SHOT ON THE P.B.R. The boat slams through the hyacinth growth, moving throug the river, FIRING BACK at unseen enemy in the jungle.

dialogues.speaker: FULL VIEW ON THE P.B.R.
dialogues.text: The boat moves ahead at half speed through a wide, flat area in the river.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: The men sit around, exhausted, brutalized, wounded. They look like animals, but they are relaxed, be- cause they know they're too far from the banks to be shot at. They smoke pot and eat silently. Lance smokes a joint and looks at his gun. Splotches of paint have been blown away from the armor shield -- pieces of deck are ripped and ragged around the mount. The boat is a floating wreck. Clean's body is being prepared in a plastic sack by Chief. All of the men are silent. Chef comes up from below; he has been wounded in the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's some bad holes, man, and the cracks -- water's coming through the cracks. Food's shot to hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much is left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Less than half -- sure is a mess down there. Chief has been silent by the body of Clean in a plastic sack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the grass?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still got a lot of that stuff from Nha Trang. But we're running low on the other. Chief pushes Clean's body into the river.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON WILLARD
dialogues.text: He notices something in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A light.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: Willard stands up, pointing up the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. They all look over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a light down there --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the middle of the jungle -- a goddamn light.

dialogues.speaker: THE P.B.R.
dialogues.text: The P.B.R. approaches the distant light -- which seems to be on the dock of an overgrown plantation building.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON WILLARD, CHIEF
dialogues.text: straining to see; he uses field glasses.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE GLASSES
dialogues.text: Seems to be some figures standing on the dock. The figures pull back behind some drums.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch it ! They duck as SHOTS RING OUT from the dock, stitching the water across the P.B.R.'s bow. The crew crouches, guns trained on the dock as the boat still approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not Cong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over the loud-hailer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're Americans. Another BURST, closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you shouldn't say we're Americans? Willard stares at the dock and building, trying to figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chef, try your French. Chief hands the loud-hailer to Chef, who shrugs and shout

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nous sommes Americains -- Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nous ne voulon pas vous agresser.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON WILLARD
dialogues.text: He looks through the glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gradually, a small group appears from behind the drums on the dock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: French Nationals -- they may not be too friendly, though.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: We drift closer to the dock. The Chef starts enjoying speaking French.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nous sommes Americains -- nous sommes des amis -- There is silence as the boat drifts closer. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vous parlez Francais comme une vache espanole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it was pretty good, myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Said I speak French like a Spanish cow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laisser tomber vos armes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put the guns straight up -- stand away from the mounts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it. They do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vous pouvez approcher mais doucement --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take her in slow.

dialogues.speaker: DIFFERENT ANGLE
dialogues.text: The men on the dock move forward, cautiously. They are a young man, PHILIPPE, about 25, strong and handsome, sav for a scar down on the side of his face and through his l eye, which is covered by a patch. He is dressed in a tiger suit and the red beret of the French colonial para- troops. Also of the red beret are HENRY LeFEVRE, a bear- ded, dark-looking man of 35, and TRAN VAN KAC, a middle- aged half-breed slave. They all bear automatic weapons and suspicious in their eyes. As the boat pulls up to the dock, another Frenchman joins the group, obviously the head man, GASTON De MARAIS, about fifty, small and deli- cate, with a strength about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hands on the heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't steer with my goddamn feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, they speak American.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is the commanding officer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am -- I'm Captain B.L. Willard. This is Chief Warrant Officer Phillips -- it's his boat. We were shot up bad downriver and need repairs and food -- we can pay you in gold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Philippe -- Philippe moves to another position -- Kac grabs the rope from the deck and ties it to the dock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll help you with --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not move -- Gaston looks at the skyward pointed twin fifties admiring

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty calibers, eh, Captain --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I said, we can pay you in gold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Entirely unnecessary, Captain. He puts down his gun -- the others do likewise --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We share a common enemy -- you are our guests. (he steps back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Gaston de marais -- this is my family's plantation. It has been such for 121 years. It will be such after I die. This is my son, Philippe -- he has fought in Algeria and held the rank of Captain. And Henry LeFevre -- a sergeant; he was at Dien Bien Phu. My personal servant, Tran Van Kac --- Then he motions to the trees. A young man in a tiger suit and three women come forward from different positions -- all wear bush clothing and bear weapons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My youngest son -- Christian --

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIAN
dialogues.text: He carries an M-60 machine gun in his hand -- a belt of ammunition trailing off behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christian's wife -- Ann-Marie -- A tall girl, goodlooking, but severe -- she carries an M-16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And my youngest daughter -- Claudine.

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDINE
dialogues.text: an attractive girl about eighteen. She wears a red paratrooper beret and a well-fitted bush suit. She carrie an M-79 grenade launcher and plenty of ammunition.

dialogues.speaker: FULL VIEW
dialogues.text: They stand there, exhausted and amazed. Philippe yells in Vietnamese -- about a dozen native men in tiger suits, heavily armed, walk out of the trees from all around them They look the Americans over warily and assemble at Philippe's command.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: American weapons?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We took them from the dead. (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now -- I assume you want to rest, to shower. We'll attend to your repairs after dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shower. Willard's men look at one another, dazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't want to bother you any, we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man of war is never bothered to  aid an ally -- you will follow me, Captain. Willard steps off -- then stops, reaches back and picks up his M-16 by the stock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A habit of men of war, sir -- you understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, Captain -- an unfortunate necessity. The men are relieved. They pick up their weapons and follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the boat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My men will keep it for you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- well, I'll stay with the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chief. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come with us. They look at each other a moment. The Chief shrugs and follows.

dialogues.speaker: PLANTATION
dialogues.text: Gaston stops, points to a guest house off the main struc- ture which is a typical jungle plantation house, save the many sandbagged gun emplacements and barbed wire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A suitable accomodation for your men, captain -- you will, of course, be quartered with us -- He indicates that the men should follow Philippe. The Chief is hesitant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead -- Philippe leads them on, muttering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain, this way. Willard follows -- they walk over past the house and towa the jungle, approaching a huge crater, 100 feet across an about thirty feet deep. The bottom is filled with water a young French and Vietnamese children swim in it. On the opposite rim, sit two men and a woman with machine guns. Gaston strides up and looks down at the crater with pride

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magnificent, eh, Captain? Willard looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is very good -- there is no current -- It is very good. I have never seen one like it in all Indochina. I was in Paris when it arrived -- do you know what might have caused --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like a two thousand pound to me. Yeah, a two thousand pound bomb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I've seen those in Normandy. This is much better. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My country -- my country could never originate this. Magnificent. Gaston stands in serious admiration for this feat; Willar looks between him and this big hole in the ground in amezement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A foreman's shower from the old plantation days. The Chief steps out of it, refreshed, though still exhausted. Lance stands there, about to step in, absolutely filthy, caked with blood. His reaction is odd; rather than just stepping into the shower, he seems almost frightened, reluctant to step in. Chef is waiting behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hot shower, hot damn. He pushes him forward into the water. The dirt and caked mud go swirling off his face and shoulders, and he relaxes as though he suddenly remenbers what a shower is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: battered and torn -- a few of Philippe's Vietnamese guard at the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful European room with tall ceilings. Still elegantly furnished, although old and decaying. Willard sits in a comfortable chair in the corner of the room, looking out over the carpet,  the bed with its elegant spread; the wash basin; the bidet. His battle dress is black with muck, with bloodstaines and burns. He rises from the chair and steps to a dresser above which is a large mirror. There is an album on the marble top of the dresser. He turns to a page at random.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON WILLARD
dialogues.text: haggard, looking down at the album.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wondered -- how long has this room been like this; how long has the furniture been standing in these places?

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE ALBUM
dialogues.text: Some old photographs of people standing around a car in the 20's in front of the plantation. Another picture shows a child playing by the rubber trees near the plantation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it like this sixty years ago? Eighty years? But here, even eighty years is nothing. He turns the page, The plantation being built. Pictures of the framing, skeletal against the sky and jungle.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON WILLARD
dialogues.text: fascinated

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was jungle, once; and it will be jungle, again...

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE ALBUM
dialogues.text: Onlu the very beginnings of the house; the first struc- tures. Then another picture of the jungle site where it was to be built.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up and sees his own face, reflected in the garis mirror. He barely recognizes himself.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: Willard looks at himself in the mirror, in this odd, out- of-time room.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT
dialogues.text: TRACK DOWN the long table, covered with delicious food. The P.B.R. crew sits with others of the De Marais group. The table is headed by St. LeFevre. Chef's face lights up as he regards the wonderful European-style food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This food is wonderful ! I can't believe the chef is a slope. (turning to Clean)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some more? Opposite the table, sitting next to the Chief, Lance reaches hungrily for bread and other food with his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey -- Lance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Oh. Um, wouldya .. wouldya pass me the Rice-a-roni, please. And then he looks to his friends for approval. Our VIEW REVEALS that behind a transparent silk curtain there is another, more elaborate table, where the De Marais family is dining with Willard. Our VIEW MOVES through the curtain and settles in a MEDIUM VIEW of the group. The men rise as a very attractive woman enters the room. Willard finally does as well, and she moves to the chair next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roxanne, I hope you are feeling better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Je vais bien maintenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I present Captain Willard? He is of a paratroop regiment. You know the difference between a paratrooper and a regular soldier, don't you , my dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling and taking Willard's hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, they come from the sky. She sits -- there's an uneasy silence. Willard is caught with this exotic woman on one side of him, and the ongoing conversation on the other. He is forced to face toward Gaston, and drawn to look at Roxann

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would like to know more about the .. uh, plaque... Philippe turns around, points to an elaborately scripted wooden plaque with various tallies on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Attacks repulsed, as I was saying. (hard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is only  for this war, Captain. Viet Cong -- 54; North Vietnamese regular forces -- 15; South Vietnamese -- 28 -- regular forces and otherwise. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Americain -- 6. Of course, they were, perhaps, mistakes, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. I -- Once we make our repairs, we could send word, we could have you evacuated from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll get blown outta here some day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will never 'evacuate', Captain -- this is our home. Indochina is ours; it has been so for a hundred and twenty-one years, there is something to say for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Vietnamese think it's theirs -- I guess the Americans do, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we civilized it. A place belongs to those who bring light to it, don't you agree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always thought the French came here to get the rubber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I must attend to my men. He gets up, and leaves abruptely -- followed by his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I ask where the Captain is going in his little boat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were going upriver when we got caught in a storm, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upriver? Why upriver? There is nothing there, only jungle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know that jungle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was a boy, my father would take me there, to hunt. There are a few savages, but no man can live there, no white man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about an American named Kurtz? There is a pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have never heard of him. Gaston rises, and takes Roxanne's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bon nuit, Roxanne -- bon nuit, Captain. Willard turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night. Gaston leaves. Willard and Roxanne are left alone. The servants clear the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must realize, Captain -- we have lost much here -- I, my husband. Gaston -- his wife and son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cognac?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should be checking on the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The war will still be here tomorrow. She walks out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so. He follows.

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD AND ROXANNE
dialogues.text: Roxanne sits, pouring a brandy, while Willard stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you miss your home, Captain? Have you someone there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was discharged from the army four years ago. I went home, wasted some time, bought a Mustang Mach 1, drove it a week. Then I re-upped for another tour. No, everything I love is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you are like us. She reaches out to him; indicating that he sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What will you do after the war?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just follow my footsteps, one at a time, trying to answer the little questions and staying away from the big ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a big question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kurtz. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you've heard of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That strange things.. terrible things have occured around this American, Kurtz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaston would never tell me. It was asubject not to be spoken of, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know -- deeper in the jungle, upriver -- there are savages?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Captain, I mean -- cannibals. A long pause. Then she looks at the cognac she poured for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a pity, you don't drink. Since my husband died, there are so many things I must do alone. She takes a sip. Willard moves to the French doors, which have been left partly open to let a breeze in. He steps onto a terrace overlooking the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A machine gun emplacement is situated on the terrace cove ing the front of house, from the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the sitting room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you warm, Captain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The river is beautiful. In fact, we REALIZE that he is checking the boat. 177  WILLARD'S POV. The P.B.R. is under guard by a couple of Gaston's Vietnamese.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW ON WILLARD, ROXANNE
dialogues.text: She, thinking it romantic to talk about the river, comes up behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spend hours watching that river from my bedroom window. It fascinates me. She moves her body close to his; and, in a moment, he is kissing her.

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD, ROXANNE
dialogues.text: One eye steals another look at the P.B.R. 180  VIEW ON THE P.B.R. Two of the guards leave -- two remain, getting ready for the long night.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON WILLARD, ROXANNE
dialogues.text: His hands wander over her body as she clings to him. Then she takes his hand, and leads him back into the sitting room, and up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is dark. She leads him into her room and closes the door. He stands there. In the center of the room is a large canopied bed with mosquito netting hanging down ove it. The windows also have netting and barbed wire -- there is a .30 calibre machine gun mount in the far one. He look around. she goes over to the bed, and turns down the sheets. Then she slips out of her dress and stands there facing him. He puts down his gun and strips off his shirt. She lays down on the bed and watches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have been lonely here, Captain. He moves to her, slipping into the bed. M-16 is leaning against the wall in his reach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can VIEW into the room, as Willard has silently slipped out of her bed, and is a dark sinister figure kneeling in final preparations for going out in the night. Without a sound, he comes out to the terrace, and scales down the wall of the old building, disappearing into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two Vietnamese guard the P.B.R. -- suddenly, feet first, the first disappears into the thicket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in the thicket; we realize he has just killed the man wit a knife. Willard stalks the second guard and makes quick work of him with his knife. He even enjoys it. Silently, he drags the body out of sight. 186  MED. VIEW ON THE P.B.R. The dark figure boards the boat silently. He disappears into the hold.

dialogues.speaker: NEW VIEW
dialogues.text: He lifts out several cases of supplies, working quickly, with a grace that indicates he is a man who has done his best work alone, and at night.

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD
dialogues.text: He sleeps soundly alone in the bed - we HEAR SOMEONE moving around in the room. He wakes suddenly -- PULL BACK TO REVEAL Roxanne combing her hair and buttoning up her blouse. She notices he is awake and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will fix you breakfast. He starts to get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I won't have time -- I gotta --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whe you reach the boat you will find that half your fifty calibre stores -- a case of grenades, a mortar and two M-16's and a case of clips are being transfered to us by your order. He stops -- seemingly stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may think what you wish, Captain, but I like you very much. She turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if I say no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Philippe will have to kill all of you. She leaves.

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD, OTHERS
dialogues.text: He walks down onto the dock. Gaston's men are transferrin ammunition boxes. Gaston is standing with Philippe, who are covering the Chief and crew with M-16's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two of my men deserted last night. It happens from time to time. I assume my daughter told you of our conditions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They taking half our ammo, Captain -- said it was your orders. He pauses for a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right -- I did. The Chief spits in the water disgustedly and starts the engines. Willard looks hard at Gaston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess this is whAt men of war do -- eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We endure, captain -- you can blow up the house and we will live in the cellar -- destroy that and we'll dig a hole in the jungle and sleep on it. Burn the forest and we'll hide in the swamp. all the while, we do but one thing -- clean the blood off our bayonets. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Au revoir, Captain. 190  LONG SHOT - DOCK - P.B.R. Willard climbs on board and it pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD, CHIEF
dialogues.text: The BOAT ROARS out across the river. The Chief looks over at Willard. They stare at each other for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time we  get in a good fire fight -- I'd like to know how she was, Captain. Willard just smiles at the Chief. he leans over and pulls up a floorboard -- the men stare in amezement; it contain the contents of all those ammo boxes.  .50 calibre; clips grenades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you put in all those ammo boxes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocks, sand -- those two men who deserted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When'd you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While you were sleeping. He lets the board drop. Willard moves to the back of the boat.

dialogues.speaker: P.B.R.
dialogues.text: The river has narrowed and runs swifter -- the water dark and deep. The trees are higher in this area and much of the river is shaded on one side. There is no undergrowth, just the tall trees and ferms. They move ahead at half speed, alert, ready for anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We moved deeper and deeper into the jungle. It was very quiet there. It was like wandering on a prehistoric planet, an unknown world ... where the men thought they crawled to, I don't know. For me, we crawled toward Kurtz -- exclusively. Willard looks out ahead and points. They all turn their guns in that direction. We PAN TO REVEAL a small village of huts along the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pass in front of the village which is rundown and completely deserted. The huts are on stilts to avoid the flooding of the river -- they are just skeletons of what they once were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- most of 'em are still standing -- might've been disease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know -- there'd still be some sign -- it's just like the one this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The canopy of trees grows taller and stretches out across the river filtering the sun. The forest itself has grown darker and more twisted with ferns and creepers. Strange birds fly out of the trees as the boat passes -- a huge snake slips along an overheading limb. The depth of the jungle is dark, ominous -- yet cool and strangely invitin

dialogues.speaker: BOAT
dialogues.text: Suddenly the river widens, the trees give way to marsh and as they emerge into the light a strange shadow falls upon the boat. It is the shadow cast by an enormous vertical tail section of a B-52 bomber thrusting out from the mud. Pieces of aluminum hang loosely from it, oxi- dizing in the sun. Creepers have already started to grow up around its heights -- the jungle is claiming it. But once under its shadow, they have passed a gateway. A gateway to paradise. The river widens and the trees at its edge are soft and seductive. The hills beyond are purple and lush. Strange orange colored water-fowl swim lazily out of their way. The water itself is glass smooth and black as if there were no bottom. The sun is warm and the breeze gentle and laced with wild gardenians. It is indeed the most peaceful valley in all the world and each man looks upon it and has never known such a sense of peace and well- being. Each man in his heart feels a need to stay -- his soul cries to stop -- stop their madness -- this spiral into hell. Here is all that can be had of earth. But no hand moves. The boat drifts on its own toward a hole at the end of the clearing. A hole into the jungle from which a darkness permeats. The boat follows the river into this hole.

dialogues.speaker: P.B.R.
dialogues.text: The skull looms in the f.g. -- the P.B.R. is pulled back about seventy yards -- Early morning mist still hangs on the water -- as it clears, we SEE another post and skulls on the opposite bank, It is strangely quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- All right, Lance -- Lance's TWIN FIFTIES split the silence as they POUR into the skulls on the opposite bank -- Suddenly there is a tremendous EXPLOSION and SECONDARY ONES from the jungle as shrapnel rips into the jungle and water from CLAYMORE MINES obviously set to cover the mound of skulls. The smoke clears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other one --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- leave it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why -- Charlie put it there to kill --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thta's not Charlie's work -- There is silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoever put'em there didn't do it to kill people -- They put 'em up as signs --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Signs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- like keep out -- Willard motions -- the Chief accelerates -- they move ahe past the smoking mound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The P.B.R. pushed deeper into this mysterious area. Mist swells in and around the river, as the boat moves into an obscure fog. The Chief cuts the engine, and they coast

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toward the night of the fifth day out of Do Lung Bridge, we judged ourselves about eight miles from Kurtz' base. Everything was still, the trees, the creepers, even the brush seemed like it had been changed into some kind of stone. It was unnatural, like a trance. Not a sound could be heard. I began to think I was deaf -- then the fog came suddenly, and I was blind too. The boat disappears in the thick fog.

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD
dialogues.text: We catch glimpses of him, even though we are close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen. They are silent. We can HEAR the most ominous SOUND COMING FROM THE BANKS. The GROANING, OR WAILING .. of HUNDREDS OF MEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're on the banks of the river.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON LANCE
dialogues.text: Frantically, he swings the twin fifties around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus !

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON CHIEF
dialogues.text: We can barely SEE him -- in and out of the fog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Lance. Not while you can't  see.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON WILLARD
dialogues.text: listening. The SOUND IS TERRIBLE, HORRIFYING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will they attack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they have boats ... or canoes... they'd get lost in the fog. We can't move either -- we'll end up on the shore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like hundreds of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhhhhh. The CHORUS OF GROANS in unbearable. But it is not ahostil cahnt; or a war chant, but rather the SOUND OF HUMAN ANGUISH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't sound hostile -- it sounds like they've seen us coming and it sounds like -- I don't know, a funeral. I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON LANCE
dialogues.text: A glimpse of him, almost in tears. We then SEE glimpses, fog moving, of all the men on the P.B.R.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: MOVING THROUGH the thinning mist. The Navy craft proceeds cautiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hours after the fog lifted, we moved slowly to a spot we thought was roughly a mile and a half below Kurtz's camp. We approached a long sand-bank stretching down the middle of the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which way? Right or left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who knows? Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks pretty shallow. The P.B.R. moves toard the right-most channel. Chef takes a long pole and begins sounding depth.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON WILLARD
dialogues.text: The men are really tense now -- Lances swivels his gun fr bank to bank. Chief keeps his fingers on an M-16. Willard takes out the TOP SECRET packet he received at Do Lung. Tears it open. We MOVE IN ON him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upon reaching objective. Target key personnel and commence operation. Should difficulty arise from which extraction is impossible, break radio silence Com-Sec Command code Strong Arm -- indicate purgative air strike -- code -- Street Gang. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Purgative air strike ! Purgative ! They'd kill me too ! Suddenly Chef lays out flat on the bow. Hundreds and hundreds of slender sticks fly onto the P.B.R. rattling against the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit ! Fucking arrows ! They're shooting fucking arrows at us.

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD
dialogues.text: looking toward the banks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frags of men -- naked limbs, arms, breasts, glaring eyes entangled in the dense jungle gloom. And hundreds of pathetic wooden arrows flying out toward them. 208 VIEW ON THE P.B.R. crazily zig-zagging up the river in the midst of the childish assault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steer her right. 209  VIEW ON THE P.B.R. arrows hitting the deck. The men open up everything they've got. Lance is FIRING the two fifties wildly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep going.. keep going. They're just fucking sticks ! Chief, stay at the helm. But Chief seems out of control -- he lets the clip of his M-16 go. Then slowly lets the rifle fall out of his hands and falls to Willard's feet, a primitive spear having caught him right through the ribs. Willard looks down in horror.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON CHIEF
