dialogues.text: laying at Willard's feet -- the long spear through him, bleeding onto Willard's boots. He looks up at Willard, about to say something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A spear? He dies. 211 MED. VIEW ON THE P.B.R. The men are still crazily FIRING into the empty jungle long after those who attacked beat their retreat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it. Stop it ! Slowly he pulls his boots from under Chief. They are absolutely soaked in blood. He is stunned -- sits down and begins to unlace the bloody boots, and take them off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chief's dead. Willard unlaces the other boot, and holds the bloody boot in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was the strangest thing -- I don't know that I can explain it. Two of my men dead, and all I could think of was whether Kurtz was dead too. That's all I wanted: to see Kurtz, to hear Kurtz. He starts to wipe the blood off the boot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somehow, in the middle of this ... carnival, Kurtz had grown into something -- a gifted officer; a great man. Somehow, he was the only light in this hopeless, hopeless darkness. And now I was too late -- he was probably gone, disappeared... by a grenade rolled into his tent -- or by some spear on the head. Christ, I felt like howling like those animals in the fog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people at Charlie's cocktail party on the boat. Some flashbulbs are going off. Some people are dancing to the MUSIC. OUR VIEW MOVES SLOWLY TOWARD Willard, on the edge of the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here they are in Los Angeles. Everything is safe. There's a supermarket around the corner, the police station around the other. It would seem ridiculous to them that I was shot to hell because I had lost the privilege of listening to the mysterious Colonel Kurtz. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I was wrong. He was waiting for me. Kurtz was alive and he was waiting for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The P.B.R. moving up the river. The men are practically in a trance now, looking at the banks of the river. They donВґt even make an effort to touch their weapons.

dialogues.speaker: WHAT THEY SEE
dialogues.text: Hundreds and hundreds of Montagnard natives -- dressed in the most ornate and primitive manner: feathers, parts of birds and animals; cod-pieces -- all in body and face paint of the most savage nature. But there is a purity about them, men and boys, standing passively watching the small Navy craft flying the strange flag of red, white and blue. 215  VIEW ON THE P.B.R. The men of the crew are not the same men who began this voyage. Their manner is lifeless as though in a trance. The various decorations and paraphenelia that they have picked up along the way seem oddly relevant to the savages that stand before them. The Chef has made a hat of birdfeathers; Lance's face has been painted with mud under the eyes to block the glare of the sun. He wears certain animal skins; trinkets; some animal teeth. Their uniforms have been torn and patched throughout the difficult journey. They start to move to their gun positions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just stand here with me where they can see us. Do nothing. 216  VIEW FROM BEHIND THE P.B.R. MOVING SLOWLY TOWARD the fantastic human wall of feathers and war paint, standing on canoes across the river. The men on the crew stand in a group, their hands visibly without weapons. The natives standing across the river make no hostile gestures as they approach. They accept the small boat moving toward them with a sort of inevi- tability. The boat moves closer, approaches the wall of feathers -- which slowly and automatically gives away, in almost a ritual of birth, undulating, allowing the little boat to penetrate.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON WILLARD
dialogues.text: Mus on his face (to protect it from the sun), the palms of some jungle vegetation protecting his head, he looks something like atribal chieftan himself. His intuition was right. He senses that they would be allowed to pass.

dialogues.speaker: FULL VIEW ON THE RIVER
dialogues.text: Hundreds of Montagnards who had been lining the river now run, absolutely silently, along the banks, keeping pace with the P.B.R. There is no hostility in these faces, only curiosity and a sort of grief.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON WILLARD, THE CREW
dialogues.text: They look up toward the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The temple at NU MUNG BA, a fortified encampment, built around the ruins of a former Cambodian civilization. Stone walls, barbed wire, cracked pyramids and rows and rows of Escher-like sandbags arranged in an endless maze around the fortress.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON WILLARD
dialogues.text: He picks up his field glasses and looks through.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH GLASSES
dialogues.text: A sign entangled in the barbed wire -- its lettering strict and military:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GLASSES POV MOVES REVEALING another sign written in a wild psychedelic hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The POV OF THE GLASSES MOVE once again and come upon an astonished sight, a black man dressed in a tatter of colored fabrics, feathers, and an Australian bush hat. He looks something like a multi-colored harlequin waving frantically to the P.B.R. The POV OF THE GLASSES MOVE OFF of him.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON WILLARD
dialogues.text: not believing what he's just seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once again the young black man is now waving his Australian hat. 225  VIEW ON THE P.B.R. Willard shouts out to the starnge greeter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been attacked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know, it's all right. Come in this way. It's mined over there. This way. It's all right. Willard look at Chef who is at the helm. He shrugs and they do as this man says. The P.B.R. moves towards the water's edge where there is a dock covered with concertin wire. The odd Australian stands waving his hat, guiding them safely in. A thick greasy smoke hangs from fires that burn near the fort; fresh shell craters indicate a recent battle. Near the dock there is a tangled clump of corpses -- half sub- merged in the water. Other piles of bodies lie about, som of them on fire. Fire literally burns from out of the ground. Chef nods at the bodies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at the Australian)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God knows. The boat pulls up. The Australian harlequin hops on board; the crew regards him with their dark faces splat- tered with mud and blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moonby. Got any Winstons?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moonby what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moonby, 4th battalion, Royal Australian Regiment, Task Force. Ex-Corporal Moonby, deserted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulously, indicating the hundreds of natives)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, they're simple enough people. It's good to see you, baby. Nobody has any Winstons? Chef automatically offers Moonby a Winston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This boat's a mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Kurtz? I want to talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you don't talk to Colonel Kurtz. (he puffs, then smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You listen to him. God, these are good. I kept these people off you, you know. It wasn't easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did they attack us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simple. They don't want him to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Australian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pre-Australian, actually. But I'd dig goin' to California. I'm California dreamin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Kurtz is alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kurtz. I tell you, that man has enlarged my mind. He opens his arms wide, to indicate the breadth of his mind's expansion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But lemme tell you, he is the most dangerous thing in every way that I've come on so far. He wanted to shoot me. The first thing he said is, 'I'm going to shoot you because you are a deserter.' I said I didn't desert from your army, I deserted from my army. He said, 'I'm going to shoot you just the same.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't he shoot you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've asked myself that question. I said to myself, why didn't he shoot me? He didn't shoot me, because I had a stash like you wouldn't believe. I hid it in the jungle; the wealth of the Orient: Marijuana -- Hashish -- Opium -- cocaine -- uncut Heroin; the Gold of the Golden Triangle. and Acid -- I make Koolaid that makes purple Owsley come on like piss. Now I'm Kurtz' own Disciple -- I listen he talks. About everything ! Everything. I forgot there's such a thing as sleep. Everything. Of love, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, not what you think... Cosmic love. He made me see things -- things, you know. The whole time Moonby is chattering on, Willard has picked up his field glasses and scans the fortress.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE FIELD GLASSES
dialogues.text: Men in small groups, huddled over food. Now he settles on the entrance in the temple. There are stakes in front, and on top of them are horrible shrunken heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like he's gone crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Colonel Kurtz couldn't be crazy -- if you heard him talk, just last week, you'd never think he was crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that where he is? By the  shrunken heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those heads, yes. Well, the rebels...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his men)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going ashore. Tie her up -- and leave your guns up, Lance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring your rifles, that's all. (looking at Moonby)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take us to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right on -- he's been waiting for --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And shut up. Moonby nods and shrugs, and hops off the P.B.R. willard and the men follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they proceed closer to the fortress-temple, men appear where a moment before there was only jungle. They are mostly Montagnards, but far more savage looking than any we've seen before. They wear only loinclothes and bandoliers of ammunition. their bodies are painted in strange patterns. They carry Army M-16's, Russian AK-47's and a wide variety of knives and clubs. Women emerge from the brush as well. they are armed and equally primitive looking. Interspersed among them are a few taller men with paler skins, with the remnants of Army insignia on them. The paint on their bodies is, if anything more bizarre. We CONTINUE TO MOVE ACROSS the entire group up to the stone gates of the fort, where thirty or so more are seen silhouetted against the sky. Willard and his men look up at people more primitive and more savage than any since the time of Captain Cook. They encounter, in the center of the group, what once appears to have been an American. he is tall, gaunt, wears a flak jacket, but is otherwise naked, save a loincloth. His face is darkened from dirt, battle smoke, strange camouflage patterns. His hair and beard are long, matted with mud and grease. He carries an AK-47 decorated with scalps and human ears. Willard approaches this beast, who seems shy and retiring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breaking in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His name is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not ever goin' to tell you to shut up again. Moonby shuts up. The MAN tries to speak, but nothing comes out. He is dumbstrucked at seeing them, as they are to see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colby. Exec. officer, A-Team... Special Forces. F-82 -- Col. Walter Kurtz, commanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What -- happened here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NVA regulars. They're coming again tonight. Tet -- their big -- assault. Willard is the man in the middle -- he doesn't know what to say to this man, but he understands the forces that pounded him. He takes his arm.

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE ON COLBY
dialogues.text: looks at Willard, not understanding.

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE ON WILLARD
dialogues.text: Six months later, and he and Colby would be identical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm taking you back. Moonby slaps himself in the head with his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, donВґt say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take us back. Take us back ! But, the operation -- the team. Colonel Kurtz has such plans for -- the team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take me to him, Major. Colby starts, and then, seeing the shrunken heads on poles, he turns, agitated, to Willard:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had nothing to do with these operations -- I did not do the planning -- none of us did. It was all Colonel Kurtz -- he was the genius. You'll see -- the genius of our Colonel. He should be made a General, don't you think? A General? It's... Suddenly, frightened, he stops. Without looking Willard knows that Kurtz is standing behind him. He turns. Kurtz has stepped out from his headquarters: He is a powerful man, though obviously very ill. He slowly attempts to pull the remnants of his uniform together, though it is ripped and bloodied, and now combined with primitive ornaments designating him a tribal chief, as well as his U.S.A. Colonel's insignia. He is feverish, with long blonde hair and beautiful features. His eyes almost hypnotize. His midsection is bandaged from what seems to be a serious wound.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON WILLARD
dialogues.text: This is not what he expected. He is quiet, and then, automatically, he comes to an attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Kurtz, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Kurtz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he salutes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain B.L. Willard reporting his presence, sir.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON KURTZ
dialogues.text: looking at him a long time. Then he returns the salute, and simply:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At ease... (pause, as he regards him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW
dialogues.text: There is, of course, no chair or anything like a chair. But behind and around him, Kurtz's men begin to sit on the ground, cross-legged. Finally, Willard sits as well. Then Kurtz does. Moonby lights a joint, and passes it respectfully to Kurtz -- throughout the scene, the joint is passed from man to man, ritualistically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you come to ... my province.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were attacked -- down river. We need supplies and medical  help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were not coming here, to see me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finding it more and  more difficult to go on with this lie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- no, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You came up my river -- in that small boat. So simple. I always thought the final justice would come from the sky, like we did. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are the final justice, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, Colonel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What other reason could you have come? A Captain. Ranger. Paratrooper. Graduate of the Recondo School. Am I right about these things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know you're right. There is a clear, incredible intelligence about this man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then the Agency approached you. Maybe in a bar in Quinon or Pleiku. Simple. A year's pay for one life. Perhaps a village elder, or a tax collector. Nobody's orders but your own. Exciting work.

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD
dialogues.text: He remains silent.

dialogues.speaker: KURTZ
dialogues.text: He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've spent tome at the Royal Tracking School of Malaysia. I can tell from the way the laces on your boots are tied. I understand you, Captain. We understand each other. There is a long pause,  as the two men regard each other. Then Willard reaches to his holstered .45 -- withdraws it, and places it on the dirt before Kurtz, as an act assuring Kurtz that he is not an assasin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Kurtz reaches down; takes the .45 -- and without another word or gesture, shoots and kills a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know me ? He throws the .45 back on the dirt. Rises, and walks back into the cavernous headquarters behind the shrunken heads. Moonby scampers off after him, a respectful distance behind. Even Willard is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dotted with campfires; Montagnard families -- it is like a primitive civilization.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW BY THE TEMPLE WALL
dialogues.text: Willard is alone by a campfire -- his M-16 leans by a wal next to him. He is exhausted. Lance sleeps by the fire, a little distance away. Chef approaches, crouches down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain -- they've been probed all this week -- Cong and NVA regulars. There's gonna be a big offense any time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Lance stirs; starts to wake up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kurtz. I'm supposed to kill him, just like he said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I can see that. He's  fuckin nuts --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He killed that guy without feeling anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you kill Cong, don't you feel something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. (thinking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Recoil... I feel the recoil of my rifle. Willard rises. Chef looks at him, confused and frightened

dialogues.speaker: WALL
dialogues.text: Willard walks along the top of a thick wall -- sandbagged and dug out every so often for an M-60 or a mortar emplacement. Wild looking savages man these guns, and seem to bow to Willard as he passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is good -- triple overlapping fields of fire -- walls so thick ordinary artillery just cleans the moss off their surfaces. A woman tentatively moves to Willard, bowing, and then runs off to her bunker. WE ARE TRACKING with them as they move past the groups of people, huddled by their fires... men, women and children. Skulls, shrunken and otherwise hang from every hut -- adorn every sandbagged bunker -- dried scalps hang from barbed wire. A child is chewing on a big piece of almost raw meat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've done things, when I was alone in the jungle -- that I never told anyone about. They continue past amount where the shattered wreck of half a helicopter is laying. It has been altered and fortified with sandbags and concertina wire. The wreck lays on its side so that a 7.62 mini-gun that was mounted there sticks up above the sandbags. The emplacement is built on amound so the gun commands a clear field of fire into the jungle beyond. Some Americans, barely recognizible because of their beards and savage manner, sit near the gun. Several Montagnard children giggle at their feet and play with bayonets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is evil -- evil, Captain. We're all gonna die here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get it -- You said your mission was to kill him. Let's do it, an' get our asses outta here. This  Kurtz is ruining the war; I mean, this don't look good for America !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lost in his thoughts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... he's an amazing officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got to kill this sonuvabitch -- Lance and me, we don'Вґt understand none of this -- Jesus, Captain -- I don't wanna die here -- Do it quick. Lance just stands there; his eyes vacant.. He sort of nods, sucking a joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I know. He thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIEW FROM INSIDE -- Willard approaches the stakes with the shrunken heads. Chef and Lance with him. Willard steps in -- Lance and the Chef crouch outside, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD'S VIEW
dialogues.text: An austere stone savern in the temple: Kurtz's head- quarters. Electric lights hanging in odd contrast to the ancient stone. We SEE what is left of the maps and other military charts -- they had been tacked up on big boards, but have now fallen into decayed disuse. There are other indications of the modern headquarters this had been. Now all those things are no longer impor- tant.  Kurtz sits alone, slumped back in a wicker chair. There is a large wooden planning table next to him, with maps, lamps and apile of debris that is practically garbage. There are native decorations to ward off evil spirits; and graffiti on the stone walls, things ranging fromm "Viet Nam, love it or leave it" to quotes of Nietzs "Nothing is true -- everything is permitted." Moonby, who had been crouching in a corner, moves to Willard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's asleep -- don't bother him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm awake. Willard steps in closer. Kurtz looks to Moonby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You. Get out. Moonby hesitates -- not wanting to leave him alone with Willard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; suddenly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said get the fuck out ! (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to kill the little weirdo myself tomorrow. (he shows some pain when moving his midsection)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HeВґs only stayed alive this long because he's a good orderly and medic. He knows how to use a hypodermic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna get hit tonight, bad -- a whole regiment of NVA regulars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, the little gook- pricks. But they are noble little gook-pricks, noble. Because they fight with their  guts, like animals. And for an idea ! That's rich. We fight with ingenious machines and fire, like Gods, and for nothing. But I'll call in a major blotto airstrike tonight. We'll have ourselves a helluva airstrike tonight, a lightshow. How do you like The Doors': 'C'mon Baby Light My Fire...' Willard shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I like it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love it. He rests back, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've gone crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. My thinking is clear. (calmly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But my soul has gone mad. Suddenly Kurtz is seized with a terrible pain from his stomach wound. He groans horribly, clutching at it. He literally falls from his chair onto the dirt floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My gut -- Oh, Christ, my gut ! Willard leans over him; checking the seriousness of the wound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance is crouching by the stone entrance -- Chef leans in witnessing the proceedings inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kill him -- come on, why don't you kill him

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Willard examining the wound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in pain)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit -- on the table; morphine. Willard moves to the table, opens the medical packet. He takes out a morphine capsule, leans over the writhing Kurtz and injects him with the drug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; looking up in pain)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see how stupid it would have been to blow out my brains? I'm dying from the gut anyway. Willard quickly prepares another shot. Kurtz, truly frightened, holds up his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- I don't want to sleep. I want to think. Water. Give me water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't have water after morphine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still playing by the rules. (almost affectionately)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a damn good kiler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still holding the second morphine)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the pain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can handle it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pain is easy to handle -- but nobility.. the nobility of a man is judged by how much Truth he can handle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What Truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truth that you were sent here to murder me, ans so far you haven't done it. And do you know why? (looks at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you know why. (he looks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mission makes about as much sense as those idiots who sent you on it. Asshole ! Schmuck !  How long does it take you to figure out that nobody knows what they're doing here. (coldly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except me. He rests back. The drug is beginning to take effect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what you're doing? You are interfering with my plans ! He crawls in pain toward the canteen Willard watches him impassively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This water's got Moonby's acid in it -- He drinks sloppily from the canteen, water spilling all over. Then he throws the canteen to Willard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drink it -- drink it for tonight. Think of it. A whole regiment of those shitty little Cong -- War. Total war -- war like you've never known it. It's beautiful -- you'll love it. Trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can SEE into the headquarters: Kurtz offers the cantee to Willard. Chef is terrified -- Lance is stoned out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance -- the fucker's not gonna do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn -- You've gotta dig napalm on Speed, too. It's spectacular, you'll see. Lance stands up holding his M-16, looks into the cavern with Chef.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willard stands there, holding the morphine needle in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look into the jungle. You can't -- it's too terrible. You have to smear yourself with warpaint to look at it -- you have to be a cannibal. (whispered)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why warpaint was invented. Then it becomes your jungle. Willard shoots himself in the arm with the morphine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did we get here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because of all the things we do, the thing we do best -- is lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think think a lie stinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Captain, that is so true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stinks. I could never figure -- (he drinks from the canteen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could never figure how they can teach boys how to bomb villages with napalm -- and not let them write the word 'fuck' on their airplanes. Willard drinks more of the LSD water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could never figure it because it doesn't make sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what makes sense ! Air strikes ! White Phosphorus ! Napalm ! We'll bomb the shit out of them if they don't do what we want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll exterminate the fuckers ! Chef steps into the Headquarters -- he is terrified. He draws his bayonet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain -- kill him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think of it -- for years, millions of years, savages with pathetic painted faces were scared shitless that fire would rain down from the sky. And goddamn, we made it happen. God  bless  Dow  !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kill him ! Chef rushes at Kurtz with his bayonet -- instinctively, Willard GUNS him -- then there is additional automatic FIRE. Chef is being riddled by bullets.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON LANCE
dialogues.text: He has let loose with his M-16 at Chef, like some sort of mindless, programmed killer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (FIRING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hot damn ! Then hes tops -- Chef falls to the dirt -- there is an instant of silence, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOORS begin LIGHT MY FIRE , loud and overwhelming, as illuminating flares light up the blackness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of enormous loudspeakers protected behind spirals of razor-sharp concertina wire. LIGHT MY FIRE is blasted out to the enemy, poised to attack.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER LOUDSPEAKER
dialogues.text: Cannibal-painted men in savage decorations wait. Bay- onets are fixed. Men are stoned to acid, injecting speed, sniffing cocaine, eating grass, smoking hashish in water pipes. One looks up to the sky.

dialogues.speaker: EIS VIEW
dialogues.text: A rocket illuminates the sky, strobing, as in a psyche- delic hallucination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow... Another behind him is chanting the word NAPALM softly t himself.

dialogues.speaker: MED. VIEW ON THE GATE
dialogues.text: Willard strides out of the darkness, into the positions around the gate. He looks like a magnificent warrior -- Genghis. All the men: Montagnards, fierce Americans, even the savage men of the P.B.R. crew either bow, salute or kneel before Willard. The color pulsates around the edge of the image, red and green, mauve and purple. We SEE Lance; waiting, with his weapons -- garlands of teeth around his neck, his face painted.

dialogues.speaker: FULL VIEW
dialogues.text: Enemy ARTILLERY BLASTING away at the fortress.

dialogues.speaker: A MORTAR
dialogues.text: A hand drops a shell and it FIRES.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKET LAUNCHER
dialogues.text: It FIRES. EXPLOSIONS around the fort, red and orange and blue and green. They hit and grow, outward like some sort of cosmic flower.

dialogues.speaker: A FLAME-THROWER, (ON TANK)
dialogues.text: Shoots out a stream of burning napalm that looks like a death ray gun, radiating outward with ice-blue energy.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT ON LOUDSPEAKERS
dialogues.text: blasting out music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the MUSIC, like those people you see listening to radios in their cars.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT ON THE COMMAND BUNKER
dialogues.text: (In SLOW MOTION) Shells WHISTLE in and EXPLODE on the walls in the compound. The men behind them are setting up rocket launcher (missile) . Everywhere metal and rock and flame fly and it is beautiful to see. Willard looks through the infra-red sniper scope.

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD
dialogues.text: Strange, luminescent images of North Vietnamese approach- ing the outer perimeters. Thousands of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mini-gun. Colby. Sergeant. Mini-gun.

dialogues.speaker: MINI-GUN
dialogues.text: A SERGEANT in feathered head-piece and wildly painted operates the mini-gun with several native helpers. SHELLS BURST  around them. When they FIRE the SOUND is incredibl loud and steady like a high-pitched foghorn. A solid stream of molten lead seems to pour into the darkness as 7000 rounds a minute rip into the enemy. The pass of the lead reaches out in beautiful patterns as the Ser- geant sweeps the area. The sergeant laughs maniacally as the GUN resumes FIRING, right up to the moment he is blown to eternity by an all-engulfing 105mm shell.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON WILLARD
dialogues.text: Exhilarated, and moving with the MUSIC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napalm. Colby pushes a row of plungers: Advancing NVAs il- luminated by napalm drums, phosphorescent napalm EXPLODES beautiful, like a magnificent firework.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claymores, claymores. The SOUND DISTORTED of tremendous HOWLING EXPLOSIONS penetrate the track of LIGHT MY FIRE one after another. Kurtz's face is illuminated by each of these. His face seems to change from one grotesgue primitive face to another, as though the whole history mankind is evolv- ing in front of us. The SCREAMS of maimed and dismembered men almost pene- trates the INCREDIBLY LOUD MUSIC and we HEAR Kurtz's men LAUGHING and SCREAMING in delight. Kurtz looks out over the field of slaughter.

dialogues.speaker: NVA CHARGE
dialogues.text: through wires and claymore glass, each wilder and more extreme. They burn in the pools of luminescent napalm but press relentlessly on. SHELL BURSTS overhead. They chant to themselves as they advance. NVA have reached the walls and throw down scaling ladders and start up. Suddenly the sky is bright with flares which produce weird psychedelic light. Blared out at tremendous vol- ume over and above the DIN OF BATTLE is LIGHT MY FIRE.

dialogues.speaker: WALL
dialogues.text: The Americans and Montagnards stand up screaming. Spurred by MUSIC, they charge up. M-16's in both hands, blasting, kicking, bayoneting, gouging, splittin throats, biting necks, both sides collide in the utter and most horrible savagery.

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD
dialogues.text: standing on the wall BLASTING as bodies fall around him; he thrusts his bayonet into one attacker, removes it with a foot and stabs another. From him he takes his AK47 and BLASTS more as they come.

dialogues.speaker: LANCE
dialogues.text: The VC rush his position. Willard trips a claymore that BLASTS most of them to shreads. More fill in. Lance opens up FULL AUTOMATIC . Willard and Lance move down to the nest wall, FIRING , bodies tumbling over. Lance is caught in a CROSSFIRE and hit several times. He pulls himself up -- FIRES a final BURST and then falls under the enemy's feet.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON MOONBY
dialogues.text: sees this and scampers off into the jungle, muttering madly to himself. 270  MED. VIEW - WILLARD AT THE R.T. shouting into the radio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Code -- Street Gang -- Street Gang ! Purgative air strike; Street Gang ! He turns and runs back through the compound with the receding Montagnards. SHELLS are EXPLODING everywhere. The light patterns are fantastic. Men fall, Viets break over the walls and charge. They crouch and rip into them FULL AUTOMATIC. They break the charge and continue cutting their way through the NVA masses like torches  through metal.

dialogues.speaker: COMMAND POST
dialogues.text: Kurtz watches as invaders swarm through his domain. Women and children rush upon him now. Kurtz flicks some switch- es and the whole north wall EXPLODES in overwhelming FIRE The gates are uprooted. The stone lions tumble, crushing men below. Kurtz cocks an M-16 and walks off the bunker.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON WILLARD
dialogues.text: watching this spectacle.

dialogues.speaker: DIFFERENT ANGLE
dialogues.text: He rounds  the shadow wall. Kurtz sees a group of Viets and rushes up and prepares a machine gun mount. They don't see him. He braces the gun at his side and steps out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles ! They stagger and fall, shattered and bleeding, save one who's merely lost his weapon. Kurtz looks at him, his gun empty. He drops it and flips open the flap of his holster. The Viet soldier goes for his pistol. Kurtz beats him to the draw and bloes him into the night. He moves over to pick up the NVA light machine gun. Holding it at his hip, he stands atop one of the ruined walls and FIRES into the masses. His native men see him and rush for the chance to die beside him. They are quickly encircled by onrushing Viets and are being overrun. The machine gun jams and Kurtz grabs a rifle. When it's empty and the bayonet is off he wields it as a club.

dialogues.speaker: LOW ANGLE
dialogues.text: taking swings with his rifle, standing atop the wall and battering the oncoming enemy like Davy Crockett at the Alamo.

dialogues.speaker: FULL VIEW
dialogues.text: The air strike hits with all its force. Balls and rain of fire sweeps down on the temple, the enemy, everything. It is the biggest firework show in history. The wall Kurtz was standing on, and he falls with it. Willard sees this and makes his way toward him as the air strike continues. All around us is a spectacle of MUSIC and light and fire and overwhelming color.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT ON WILLARD
dialogues.text: following Kurtz's trail in the mud. He has crawled on all fours back into the jungle to die. He stalks Kurtz into the jungle ; moving around and cutting off the crawling Kurtz

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go away -- hide yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going back  - to the jungle to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm taking you back. You can  still live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had immense plans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna get you out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was on threshold of great  things. Willard slings Kurtz's bleeding body around his neck, holding his hand, dragging hom through the jungle. The spectacle continues in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This wreck of a boat is still afloat. Willard crawls out of the jungle, carrying the dying Kurtz and manages to get him onto the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The spectacle of total psychedelic war: the fortress of Nu Mung Ba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire temple is devastation. Vultures by the hundred circle overhead. There are a few survivors. Everywhere is smoke and heaps of bodies. Colby, a Sergeant, and some Montagnards sit near them. Their eyes are red and glazed, their jaws hang slack and they tumble occasionally. They stagger away from the field of slaughter. Willard looks down and sees something Moves over to it, kicks several bodies away and in the f.g. below is Lance, dead. Colby stumbles over. Willard holds Lance up by his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was the tragedy -- the tragedy of this war.

dialogues.speaker: THE P.B.R.
dialogues.text: battered, moving slowly down the river.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHTER VIEW
dialogues.text: Colby is at helm. Kurtz lies feverish, delirious. Willard sits by him. As the boat moves, Montagnards, thos left alive, come and pay their respects by the riverbanks Colby takes an automatic weapon and FIRES it into the air Some of the natives move in terror, frightened of him. The battle is not over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't. Don't frighten them away. Willard looks down at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you understand this? Kurtz looks up at him, past him with fury, longing in his eyes. There is a slight smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boat moves as though naturally carried by the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My river... my people... my jungle... my ideas... my country...                  my wife... (he looks at Willard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... my death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had immense plans... immense plans...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm taking you back. Kurtz looks up to him, then an expression of overwhelming intense and hopeless terror, hopeless despair. A whisper at some image, at some vision, he cries out twice, a cry that is no more than a breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The horror, the horror. We HEAR the distant SOUND of HELICOPTERS approaching. The SOUND of ROTORS in the distance. They look up, craning their eyes at the sky. Colby points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There. Over the jungle mountains the small formation of MEDEVAC helicopters hooping toward them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did they know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They must have seen the fire. The helicopters are closer now but high up. Two of them breaking off, spiraling in TOWARD US.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're coming to rescue us. They're Medevac.

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD
dialogues.text: He stares up at the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're coming to take us back. Copters directly overhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Kurtz, he's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. He raises his M-16 and FIRES the entire clip at the ap- proaching rescue helicopter.

dialogues.speaker: THE COPTER
dialogues.text: It frantically pours on the power and wheels up to the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Colby takes his rifle and joins Willard in FIRING at the retreating American helicopters.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE BOAT
dialogues.text: The men in the boat FIRING AT US as we fly further into the air, the boat getting smaller and smaller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Don't remember a lot about my rehabilitation... but I was sent back to the world before the fall of Saigon...

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: MOVING DOWN back to the pleasure boat at the Marina. Pause. Willard is very silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never answered questions about Kurtz -- I gave them a few of his unimportant papers -- but for the most part I saved everything. There were other letters, personal ones written earlier to his wife. I brought them to het. I watched the fall of Saigon on television in a bar in Alameda...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bright clear day in a scrubbed-clean California neigh- borhood. Some kids are playing in the street. Willard, years later, dressed as a civilian, proceeds pas the lawn to the attractive home, carrying a packet under his arm. He passes a lanky, young teen-aged boy working on a motor-scooter. Willard looks at him. The boy looks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Then the door opens, and KURTZ'S WIFE is standing at the door. She is still beautiful, blonde, and dressed in mourning even though she doesn't wear black. There is a sense of purity about her, though she is not young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in, Captain Willard. He enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything good and secure and desirable about America. She stands in the center of the room, a little nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get anything for you? There are pictures of Kurtz, not too many... but he is there in the various stages of his career. Then she sits suddenly, and Willard sits by her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know him very well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get to know each other pretty well out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you admired him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a remarkable man. It was impossible not to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love him... Yes, it is true. That's the hard part for me... I knew him better than anyone ... I knew him best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You knew him best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were his friend... You must have been, if he had given you this... (the packet)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he sent you to his home. He was the best this country had -- he was --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll never get over it -- But I'll always remember him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both of us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men looked up to him... (she loses herself in a thought)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He died as he lived...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His death was -- yes, he died as he lived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you with him, when...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I was... He said his last words to me. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD
dialogues.text: A little of the madness is still with him. He knows what she will ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: WILLARD
dialogues.text: remembering that incredible day moving down the river. Our VIEW LOOSENS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me what he said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The horror ! The horror !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He spoke of you, ma'am. He sits there looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: THE MARINA DEL REY BOAT
dialogues.text: The cocktail party is breaking up. Willard is one of the few guests left. We MOVE FROM Willard standing alone on the deck of the boat. Moving back through the departing guests. Charlie is getting ready to leave himself. We MOVE CLOSER to Willard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the boat floating down the river. Kurtz's body; an exhaus ed, half-dead Colby. And HOLDING Kurtz, Willard. We HEAR THE DOORS' "THE END" as we present the END TITLES.
